name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Thursday, 17 September 2015.

name: Goffredo Maria BETTINI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to ask permission to say a few words about the death of Pietro Ingrao.  Ingrao was a great personality of Italian politics, a builder of democratic institutions, a father of the left, for me the most important. He was a very authoritative part of the management of the PCI for decades and I had him as a master. With him goes the most anomalous, open, suggestive, popular and empathetic Italian communist. His strength was not anchored in an ideology, on the contrary it springed from life, from experiences, from emotions, even in their corporeity, generated from the contact – as he himself will say for him psychically unbearable – towards the injustice that is exercised on the last or, rather, on offenses.  For this reason his thought, which he wanted to keep to the last part, nevertheless had a great universal intensity. I wanted to address this thought to Ingrao because he was a man certainly in many moments forced in his time, but capable of living an authentic inner freedom.

name: Olaf STUGER
text: – Thank you chairman. I would like to share some good news from the Netherlands with colleagues. The Dutch people will soon be able to go to the polls to determine the future of the association agreement with Ukraine in a referendum. We all owe this to the citizens' initiative GeenPeil, which has collected 500 000 signatures. So what D66, a political party, has not succeeded in 50 years, this citizens' initiative has succeeded in 50 days, a referendum. So that deserves a congratulatory note and I'll keep you posted on the outcome.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The final draft agenda as drawn up pursuant to Rule 149 by the Conference of Presidents at its meeting of 1 October 2015 has been distributed. The following changes have been proposed: Tuesday:  The Group of the European People’s Party (Christian Democrats) has asked for a statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/ High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Georgia and the use of selective justice, namely the case of Gigi Ugulava, to be included on the agenda in the afternoon, with a resolution. I give the floor to Mr Preda to move the request on behalf of the EPP Group.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group – Madam President, the PPE Group wishes to include this subject, namely a discussion on Georgia and selective justice in that country. It is a very serious subject, I think we need to deal with the issue of the independence of justice and the relationship between politics and justice in Georgia. I appeal to liberal colleagues and socialist colleagues, who know that they very warmly support the power of Georgia. The theme we are proposing is important and I would urge them to vote in support of us. In particular, I am addressing the Socialists, who, moreover, support within the European Union a Prime Minister, who is also the head of the Social Democratic Party of Romania, who is being sued, and I think it would be time to part with him. Thank you for your attention.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Madam President, I wanted to say that I generally support all initiatives aimed at condemning selective justice. What I would like is for us to also look, in line with what our EPP colleagues say, on selective justice as it is practised within the European Union: for example, on selective justice in Greece, against Golden Dawn MEPs, for example on selective justice in Germany, on selective justice in France , precisely because of liberticidal laws. All this would be an extremely favourable action theme for our Parliament. (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: – Madam President, I think it is quite significant that Mr Preda's proposal was fervently supported by Mr Gollnisch. But what this is all about is not discussing this particular case, but the way this Parliament worked. This is an emergency proposal which the People's Group had already put forward at a later time and which did not get sufficient support, and now comes to the plenary to see if it can be introduced into plenary. It seems to me that, irrespective of the subject in question, it is not an acceptable procedure in the functioning of the House.

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group, I would like to make a ido to the Council of Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her My group is asking for a debate, without a resolution, on the deadly US airstrike on the doctors Without Borders hospital in Kunduz, in accordance with the Rules of Procedure. The item was to be debated on Wednesday morning – in our view at 8.30 a.m. – in the presence of the High Representative, Mrs Mogherini. And in order to accommodate some groups, I also propose that we do so as a round of group spokesmen. Last Saturday, October 3, 12 staff and at least seven patients, including three children, were killed by Us Army attacks on the hospital. Thirty-seven people, including 19 employees, were seriously injured. According to Doctors Without Borders, the trauma center of Doctors Without Borders in Kunduz was hit by several airstrikes between 2.08am and 3.15am on October 3. The central hospital building, which contained the intensive care unit, emergency rooms and a physiotherapy ward, was repeatedly hit every time the attack was carried out, very precisely. As early as September 29, the hospital's geo-data was communicated to the international coalition as well as to the Afghan military and civilian authorities, but the bombings occurred. EU countries are involved in the war in Afghanistan. However, the EU is also involved in development aid, even more than in any other country. Many aid organisations from Europe, including Doctors Without Borders, are involved. That is why we are calling for clarification!

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her On behalf of my group, I support the motion, which Gabi Zimmer has just justified very well. I must say beforehand that I am relieved by the speech and communication of President Obama, who has already announced a full investigation into these terrible events in Kunduz. However, I think that we also need an international debate on what has happened, especially because the development in Afghanistan as a whole is frightening and I believe that we have not had a discussion on it so far. In view of the debates we are having tomorrow, I think that, in line with the world situation, there is every reason to put this item on Afghanistan on the agenda for the terrible occasion that Mrs Zimmer has described.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: – Madam President, the matter I want to raise is not strictly speaking on the agenda, but it relates to the debate on Tuesday on, let us say, ‘dieselgate’. I understand that the Conference of Presidents had agreed to request the presence of Vice-President Timmermans for this debate. But we see on the schedule that Commissioner Bieńkowska, who is in charge of entrepreneurship, industry and the internal market, will be there. Given the seriousness of the issue and the fact that it touches upon environmental policy, competition policy, governance and maybe other issues as well, and given that there are four committees involved in his issue, we would like to know why the Commission has not met our request to send Vice-President Timmermans for the debate.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: It is for the Commission to decide who participates in the debate and I dare say that Commissioners, when they are here, speak on behalf of the Commission. But your point is made. I have had no proposal for a change to our agenda for Thursday so the order of business is established. (The order of business was thus established)

name: Morten MESSERSCHMIDT
text: – Madam President, I wish to raise a point on the Wednesday part of the agenda, referring to what you said earlier on our upcoming vote on the calendar. The deadline for tabling amendments is tomorrow, and the ECR Group has submitted an amendment limiting the number of days in a Strasbourg session from four to three. That has been deemed inadmissible by Mr Schultz without any clear reasoning. One hour ago I received an email in which somebody from Parliament’s administration stated that this would be contrary to the case-law on the Protocol. I do not think, in the light of the sensitivity and the political importance of this issue, that that is a well-reasoned justification for deeming an amendment inadmissible. I would therefore like to request that the Presidency comes with a much more in-depth analysis of the true impact of the Court decision of 2012 on what we can and cannot do in this Chamber in respect of amending the calendar, because without a strategic in-depth analysis, it makes no sense for us to vote on the calendar or to be encouraged to amend it.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: I think you will be aware that this issue arose in 2014, and at that point the same amendment was ruled inadmissible on the basis of the President’s legal interpretation, which was delivered to him. Nothing has changed since, the President’s ruling and decision is final in this regard, and the amendment is inadmissible. We have noted your comments.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: – Madam President, I am intervening on the emergency agenda on Thursday morning. This is the second time in recent months that, instead of three topics on the emergency agenda, we have four topics and intervene to recall what Article 135 of the Rules of Procedure says, which states: "The total number of topics on the agenda may not be more than three, including sub-items.". I understand that we have four subjects because President Schulz insisted on adding a fourth, in violation of the Rules of Procedure a second time. I would like to reduce the number of emergency topics to three, as required by the Regulation, because having four topics means reducing the debate time for each of them. I don't think we should break our rules. Thank.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Thank you, Mr Preda. My understanding very clearly is that there was agreement in the Conference of Presidents on this issue and that there was to be no request to change the agenda, but you have made your point very well and we will pass this on to the President and to the relevant services.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the report by Iskra Mihaylova, on behalf of the Committee on Regional Development, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down common provisions on the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund and laying down general provisions on the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund as regards specific measures for Greece (COM(2015)0365 – C8—0192/2015 – 2015/0160(COD)) (A8—0260/2015).

name: Iskra MIHAYLOVA
text: Rapporteur. – Dear Madam President, honourable Members, I have today the opportunity to submit to the European Parliament a legislative report on the proposal to amend Regulation No 1303/2013 on common provisions concerning specific measures for Greece. First, I wanted to start by saying that this is an exceptional situation that needs to be addressed with specific measures. Each of us followed the summit on 12 and 13 July, when eurozone leaders reached an agreement to support Greece, each aware of the need for urgent action, both the leaders of the euro area and the European Commission and, of course, the European Parliament. In this respect, Parliament's committees decided on a simplified procedure without amendments to this Regulation in order to contribute to the general conditions for supporting Greece and to allow the Regulation to enter into force as soon as possible.  On 17 July, the European Commission presented a legislative proposal that also includes exceptional measures and aims: First, to increase the level of initial pre-financing for cohesion policy operational programmes for the period 2014-2020 under the Investment for growth and jobs goal and for programmes financed by the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund in Greece. Secondly, increase the maximum co-financing rate for operational programmes for the period 2007-2013 under the Convergence objectives and the Regional Competitiveness and Employment goals in Greece to 100% and remove the payment ceiling under these programmes. Through this change of regulation, the proposed measures aim to address a critical liquidity gap in the Greek economy and provide an immediate and necessary investment incentive, enabling a faster launch of a larger number of projects. This proposal is budget neutral for the period 2014-2020. All colleagues have agreed to apply the simplified procedure. As regards the Committee on Regional Development, no member has objected to this procedure. However, the Council, chaired by Luxembourg, also considered this dossier to be urgent and will follow Parliament if it accepts the Commission's proposal as it is. If Greece does not speed up the pace of its payment applications for the programmes concerned before the end of 2016, it faces the risk of recovering the additional initial pre-financing. Last but not least, Greece should submit a report to the Commission on the implementation of these exceptional measures. In order not to end up with only technical aspects, I would like to stress that we are here in this plenary as representatives of the citizens of the European Union and we can express our concern. We might think that we now have more pressing problems, but we must also respect our commitment to supportIng Greece here and today. For this reason, I call on you to support the proposal.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, on behalf of the Commission, I would like to thank Parliament for supporting the proposal to amend the Common Provisions Regulation as regards specific measures for Greece. The proposal is an exceptional measure to address the unique situation in Greece. The Commission’s proposal follows the agreement reached in July at the Euro Summit. The agreement reached between co-legislators to maintain the Commission proposal – and the exceptional speed which with which they processed this – is a concrete sign of European solidarity. The proposal must be seen in the wider context of the reform process undertaken by Greece. Timely and effective implementation of reforms to modernise the state and the economy, as agreed under the third programme, is crucial to ensure financial stability, fiscal sustainability and sound economic fundamentals for investment, job creation and growth. It is crucial to dispel any uncertainty and ensure a sound financial sector. With capital controls in place, the financing streams of the real economy are strained at a time when investment is needed most. The EU funds have an important role in this respect. There are substantial means available from the EU budget for Greece but the implementation of the project, co-financed with EU funds, is held back by the tight liquidity situation of the Greek state. To help address this situation we have put forward three exceptional measures so that the investment supported by EU funds can take place, and take place swiftly. For the 2014-2020 period, it is proposed to increase the rate of initial pre—financing for Greece by seven percentage points for the European Regional Development Fund, the Cohesion Fund, the European Social Fund and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund. This frontloading should allow for starting more investments earlier.  For the 2007-2013 period, two measures are proposed: firstly to release the last five percent of the remaining EU payments, which are normally retained until the closure of the programmes in 2017 and, secondly, to remove the obligation to provide for national cofinancing and to apply the 100% EU financing rate. These measures should help bring the investment finance for the 2007-2013 period to a successful conclusion. All these measures would translate into EUR 2 billion available for Greece over the two years 2015 and 2016. Importantly, these measures are budget-neutral for the current Multiannual Financial Framework and would have no impact on the payment plan either. The additional pre-financing for the 2014-2020 programmes should be covered by payment application by the end of 2016. It is, of course, crucial to ensure that the money duly reaches the beneficiaries and does so as quickly as possible in line with the rules of sound financial management. To this end, a ring-fencing mechanism will ensure that additional amounts for the 2007-2013 period are used only for payments to beneficiaries. Greece has already put such a mechanism in place. Moreover, Greece is required to report on the implementation of these measures by the end of 2016 and in the final implementation report for the 2007-2013 period. The Commission has stood by Greece throughout the crisis with both financial support and technical assistance. We will continue to support Greece, both in the implementation of the reforms and in making the best use of EU funds.  Technical assistance is already being provided through the new Structural Reform Support Service which is available to all EU Member States. Technical meetings and ad hoc missions on the ground are being organised. As it happens, Commissioner Crețu is in Greece today. I am looking forward to your debate.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for This is, of course, an extraordinary procedure that is never really easy for the Committee on Budgets. In the previous period, I was one of the shadow rapporteurs for the so-called troika report. We had an opportunity to see all the problems facing the Greek economy. For this reason, I believe that it is a good deal of assistance on the part of Parliament to approve this proposal. At the same time, we know that Greece also came under pressure during the refugee crisis that was too great for the weak economy to bear. At the same time, however, I would like to be extremely clear on one point. We occasionally receive reports on the way in which Greece deals with euro money. In Greece, there is a Turkish minority that sometimes feels badly treated, and we will be very careful in following up on this so that the Turkish minority gets its fair share of this money. Then I cannot help but say that we hope that this will be the spark – in Bulgarian iskra – that ignites a better future for Greece.

name: Thomas HÄNDEL
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. The Employment Committee in the European Parliament clearly welcomes this action by the Commission. We believe that Greece urgently needs help after the years of crisis. We particularly welcome the fact that frontloading is taking place. In particular, we welcome the fact that there is no need for any own subsidies from Greece. Greece urgently needs help. During the crisis, more than 250 000 businesses in Greece went bankrupt and were destroyed. In this respect, we urgently and quickly need aid for Greece. Personally, I would warn against saying too quickly now that we want a monitoring of success. It takes time to start this development and, above all, it takes time to make other investments that go beyond that, so that Greece has the chance to get out of this crisis, out of this crisis with European solidarity and help, and not, at the same time, destroy labour rights. We have to wait for this process. Patience is needed, including in this House. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: "blue card" question. Madam President, my speech is not about what Mr Händel said, but about the previous speaker, who said that there is a Turkish minority in Greece. That's not the case, it's false. There is no Turkish minority in Greece. There is only a Muslim minority and there is no need to give money to it. (The Chair interrupts the speaker)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Mr Epitideios, I am sorry but you should have addressed the question then, so I am not going to allow it.

name: Lambert van NISTELROOIJ
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, my first point would be on the situation in Greece itself. As regards the whole package of the Juncker proposals and the related agreement reached in the summer, it is absolutely necessary that we deliver. Therefore, this fast-track procedure is the correct response to this specific situation. Secondly, the most important requirement – which is to have money available to finalise the projects that can benefit from this proposal – is what is at stake this evening and in tomorrow’s vote. But there is another aspect I want to touch upon, which is the control that Parliament wishes to exercise on the regional funds. The EPP Group has proposed that in this case for Greece – and especially regarding these measures where we take away co-financing and for which we pay 100% of the money needed for projects – we have a say on the matter and special control. That is why the EPP Group proposed, in the debate at the Committee on Regional Development, to have a special rapporteur, a permanent rapporteur, on Greece.  Greece now is the only country where 100% European funding is necessary. As has just been said by the rapporteur, it is a sign of solidarity in Europe. But on the other hand, we want to be sure that this money is going to the projects for which it is intended, and that the full control that applies to every other country in Europe, according to the regulations, is applied in the Greek situation. That is why it is a ‘yes’ from the EPP for this fast-track proposal to use this measure for the money for 2014-2015; but also a ‘yes’ for a new role for Parliament, with a specific rapporteur.

name: Constanze KREHL
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which First of all, I would like to thank the Commission for putting such a proposal on the table so quickly, after months of tug-of-war, after the Council took months of tug-of-war to actually express itself jointly on the fate of Greece. It is the right answer. After the unilateral austerity policies of recent years, we now finally need investment in the Greek economy. How else can this country get on its feet if investment is not made? The only instrument that the European Union has for this is cohesion policy. We must finally make good use of this! The projects which have also been selected for the old funding period have been selected together with the Task Force for Greece set up by the Commission. And this task force has always been there for reporting in the Committee on Regional Affairs and has accompanied the projects that are now to be 100% funded in Greece in the coming months. What perhaps not every member of this house knows is that if we do not release this money, Greece will not only have the problem of having to pay 5%, but it will have to refund to the Commission the entire 95% that these projects have already cost. That would be an absolute disaster. Of course, there is a need for control. Everywhere must be checked. It is up to us as a Parliament to accompany this. That's right! But to pretend now – and unfortunately some colleagues are doing so – as if this were now a tragedy, that we are taking money in our hands in a budget-neutral manner in order to support Greece, to support the labour market and economic development, I do not think that is appropriate. I hope that tomorrow we will not only have an overwhelming majority, but that we will have a majority as large as possible, in order to turn this sign of solidarity into practical reality. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". You said 'there is no investment' and 'there is a need to invest, that is why the funds are needed'. Have you ever wondered why not invest? Why does no one go with their money and invest in Greece? Why doesn't this happen? They always say, "It doesn't happen," but the question is: why?

name: Constanze KREHL
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. – At the moment, it is true that the State of Greece has no free money at all to invest anything, which is explicitly the result of the corresponding austerity policy of the troika, not just the European Union. We really need to send out a clear signal. It is the case all over the world that, in certain crisis situations, the public authorities have to make advance payments. That is money from the Cohesion Fund that Greece is entitled to. We allow the output to actually be made.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: on behalf of the ECR Club. - Madam President, the introduction of specific rules that should allow for better and more efficient use of EU funds should in any case make it easier for Greece to address illiquidity, but the question arises whether it will contribute to the Greek recovery to the extent we would like. Greece must implement reforms that the Cypriot government ran away from last term, and voters recently rewarded it for this behaviour. I believe, therefore, that there will be no significant breakthrough for the better in implementing structural reforms in the coming period, which makes our efforts to help Greece somewhat futile. The proposal highlighted that Greece lacks the funding for public investment needed to foster a sustainable recovery. I believe that to be true, but I must express disagreement with such a strategy. Increasing government spending will certainly not lead the state out of the crisis because such irresponsible behaviour has introduced it. For our efforts to make any sense, the new Greek government must attract private investors and strengthen the private sector at the expense of the public. Is the Cypriot government ready for that? By what measures does he plan to achieve this? I'm afraid these moves don't help our Greek friends and partners in the long run, we push them deeper into the abyss. If Greece were not a member of the eurozone, in which it was admitted under suspicious circumstances, it would be visibly more difficult to borrow all these years and would be in much less trouble today. We may have stopped giving unconditional gifts to Greeks with European taxpayers' money, but we continue to encourage them to spend excessively with these formulations that make public investment a precondition for sustainable recovery.  A sustainable recovery in Greece can only be achieved by reducing public spending, cutting public sector cuts, reducing administrative burdens and attracting private capital. Everything else is a mere life from which both Greeks and European taxpayers are tired.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. – Madam President, Mr Commissioner, I will say right at the outset that this is an excellent proposal from the Commission. It comes at the right time, recognises the problems facing Greece for many years and the Commission has shown maturity at the moment, and I want to say that, in all likelihood, Parliament will do the same. This Parliament will take by accelerated procedure all those necessary decisions in order to express to the Greek people at the moment the solidarity of the European Union, the Commission and parliament and all those who decide, and thus to help all those we know need help in Greece. In this context, the ALDE group, on whose behalf I speak here, supports this expedited procedure. Our rapporteur, chairwoman of the Regional Development Committee, did everything she could. At the meeting of our Committee we saw the need for an accelerated procedure without much formality, all that is at our disposal, precisely with the aim and with the only desire to help Greece.  Estimates suggest that around €2 billion will be saved for the Greek budget here, that almost 1 billion will accumulate further for the needs of the Cohesion and Structural Fund, as well as the Maritime and Fisheries Fund. These are significant assets. It will not solve all the problems in Greece, but it will be a very concrete and clear means that will bring a new chance for Greece and for the Greek government from which we expect a lot.  The Greek government went to the polls, recently regaining confidence. Cipras spoke here in Parliament, promised reforms. We expect these reforms. We expect the new government to respond in the way we have shown. We have shown solidarity, we have shown the decision to help Greece, but we also expect the Greek government to deliver on its promises it has made to Europe and thus do what we all expect – to make Greece a true part of our great European family again. It is an emergency situation, and an emergency situation requires extraordinary measures. We did it. Now we expect their moves from Greece. (Speaker agreed to answer the question "blue card" (Article 162(8) of the E.S. regulation)).

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: blue-card question. – Rushed legislation is often bad legislation. I note particularly the five questions raised by the Committee on Budgets on 14 September 2015 concerning this legislation. Do you feel that the Commission has provided a sufficient response to those questions?

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. - I read the opinion of the Budget Committee, I saw that there are adequate reservations of the Budget Committee, but I believe that what the Commission has offered, and the way we handled it in the Regional Development Committee, guarantees that this money will be spent properly because otherwise, of course, we will have to react. So, I find, as I said in my speech, that this is a good proposition and needs to be realized.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, Commissioner, we are not here to debate the content of the third memorandum, although there is much to be said for. Indeed, the only choice left, basically, to the Greek government was to survive or die.  It was the choice of survival that prevailed. This choice of survival is a priority to respond immediately to the liquidity needs that we know are sorely lacking and to be able to commit European funds quickly. For this, it is not urgent to wait but it is urgent to act. That is why we support the fast-track procedure. There is also an urgent need for action to enable Greece to return to investment. It is with this urgency in mind that we now support the exceptional measures proposed by the Commission, namely 100% co-financing, facilitation of pre-financing and the immediate release of European funds. A total of two billion euros. What I also mean is that we see, with this regulation, that it is the cohesion policy, this regional policy which, once again, is the only one able to implement solidarity. It is regional policy that is the only one able to temper the disastrous effects of austerity policies.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, today we are thanked above all for the Greeks and Europeans. From the outside, we are now discussing very technical issues. We are talking about 7% more pre-financing, we are talking about two billion more co-financing from the European side, more rapid release of the 5% payment and technical administrative support. Outside this House and the Commission, few citizens probably understand what it means. In essence, however, we are discussing much, much more today. This is because it is a central decision of direction within the European Union. It is a question of whether we manage to solve pragmatic problems together in a crisis situation, or whether we sacrifice these solutions on the altar of populism. Right-handedness has repeatedly led to dead ends in Europe in the past. Only negotiations on an equal footing and reliable solutions can pave the way for a positive development in Greece. The Commission's proposal takes up just that. After all, the one-sided austerity policy of recent years has failed. The tough conditions, including from the European level, have helped to bring the Greek economy to the ground today. And now we have come to the point where the Commission also sees that we must turn words into deeds. The fact that Greece can benefit more quickly and easily from a European investment policy is a first step in the right direction. Because with these European structural funds, we have a very strong instrument in our hands to get Greece out of this impasse. That is why the investments must now flow. 25% of all public investment in Greece is from European structural policy. In order to boost the economy, this money must now be available, not in any way, but in a very targeted manner, for meaningful projects that create jobs that are environmentally sustainable and transparent. That is another reason why the fourth point in this proposal , the point on technical assistance – is so central. The Greek administration must now do a great deal, hand in hand, with the European Commission, in order to implement these projects in a meaningful way. There is a great deal ahead of us. Only if we move away from the national petty spirit can we manage to do so with common European forces. That is why the question arises today as to whether we are reliable European partners on this point too and whether we, as Europeans, stand alongside Greece, in these tough circumstances and in this tough situation. My group says yes! Right now, what European solidarity means is clear. That is why we support the Commission's proposal as a first step in the right direction.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: au nom du groupe EFDD. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in view of the tragic situation in Greece, the 5-Star Movement is obliged to vote in favour of the proposal to increase cofinancing for the old programming and pre-financing advance for the current one. The 5-Star Movement has always advocated a policy of greater flexibility towards the Greek people, sharply criticising the austerity policies and the way in which the memorandum was negotiated that were imposed on Greece. I would stress that the proposal does not involve any change in the annual ceilings for commitments and payments provided for in the multiannual financial framework and that the annual allocation of commitment appropriations for the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund and the Cohesion Fund remains unchanged.  I would also like to point out that there is a mechanism in place to ensure that the amounts are used exclusively for payments to beneficiaries and for operational programmes, that is to say for citizens. The 5-Star Movement therefore votes positively but, mind you, our vote on these individual measures does not shift by a comma our assessment of the vexatious treatment imposed on Greek citizens in the name of austerity, budgetary constraints and rules that apply only to some and less to others.  I would also like to stress the enormous effort and great humanity that the Greek people, despite the very difficult conditions in which they find themselves, have shown in welcoming migrants who are men and women fleeing wars or in search of a better future and not, as is often passed in public, clandestine speeches. Article 80 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union refers to the principle of solidarity, and Article 174 states: 'In order to promote the harmonious development of the Union as a whole, it shall develop and continue its action to strengthen economic, social and territorial cohesion'.  Do you believe that the European Union, in its different declension of the Commission, the Council and the majority of this Parliament, is really applying these principles? We need only cite the example of the economic macro-territoriality applied to cohesion policy in order to give us an unfortunately not at all reassuring answer.  (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Olaf STUGER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – For the government, including the EU, there is only one way to get money and that is through taxes. Let that taxpayer here always be the third of the party.  If we look at such a typical taxpayer's day in the Netherlands, it starts at nine o'clock in the morning. Until his coffee break at 11:00, he works for taxes. After his coffee break until his lunch, he works for the tax. After lunch he also works for more than an hour before the taxes and only at ten before 3:30 pm he starts working for himself. At least, it was until recently. But since we decided here to transfer billions, hundreds of billions to Greece, this Dutch taxpayer has spent 7 minutes of extra time working for the tax. So today he works until about 3.30pm for taxes, and I hope that the Commissioner, that the Commission, when they sip their tea around that time, want to take a moment to think about it. Thank you very much.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Madam President, first of all let us make it clear that the increased pre-financing that is being talked about concerns investments in the profitability of businesses, and it is the other side of the unpopular policy of the barbaric third memorandum that our people pay dearly in Greece, with new barbaric measures of government and quartet, demolition of insurance, industrial relations, tax-looting and privatisation.  The European Union's funds are raised by the bleeding of the people, they come from the state budget which redistributes resources at the expense of the people's families, in favour of their monopolies, competitiveness and profitability. Even the minimum funds for employment translate into subsidies for businesses, and become a vehicle for imposing galleon work conditions for a few months, which recycle unemployment and are also a tool for the uprooting of small farmers.  A great proof of where this money is going is the funds, which were even absorbed 90% in 2007-2013, which were just being cut off from monopolies at the same time as the working-class family went bankrupt. The only way for the people is to organise the struggle in a line of rupture with the European Union and the monopolies to put obstacles in the way of the promotion of measures, to recover losses, to pave the way for the people to become the owner of the wealth they produce.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, today we are taking the last steps of a race, a sprint that we have done here in the European Parliament, so that the Greek economy can finally be directly involved with a total benefit of EUR 2 billion in principle. This is certainly an exception, an exception for Greece, and we have heard objections, objections from governments, objections from colleagues in the Committee on Regional Development, which are reasonable. Why should we give Greece an exception and not pay the national contribution? Why should we emphasise pre-financing, at a time when others need money, the Greek government does not seem to be rushing? The answer comes from what Greece has experienced and is experiencing. Greece, my country, has lost 30% of Gross Domestic Product during the economic crisis. It is experiencing conditions of war and at the same time prolonged political instability has increased uncertainty at all levels.  Now, after the new government has been formed, it is necessary to explain that the support of the European Union is essential for the unfedible implementation of structural reforms. Tomorrow we are voting on the amendment of the Rules of Procedure, and the European Parliament will once again show its solidarity with our country in record time.  After that, it is the sole responsibility of the Greek government to take the baton, to run the reforms, to seize the opportunity given to Greece. The fight to restart the Greek economy is a marathon and we must keep our eyes on Greece. Let's see how the reforms go, know what's going on there at all times.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: Madam President, let me be a little ironic in praising the ingenuity of our European leaders, because even if I support the proposal, really, to advance a billion euros to Greece, to ask it in return to better liquidate its public assets and destroy its social fabric and its pensions, all this without offering any lasting solution to the Greek economy, decidedly it is not expensive to pay. I would have liked our negotiators to be so inventive to the Americans in negotiating the transatlantic treaty, but it seems that today Europe is strong against the weak and weak against the strong. I know that the Commission could not have proposed a better one, but let me doubt, not the merits of this pre-financing, but its budgetary sincerity. We have 24 billion unpaid bills in the pipeline this year, who will pay that billion? The states that made that decision? We know here that they will not add a euro. Either, again, it will be project owners who will not see their bills paid for a long time, or this commitment will remain a dead letter. This is enough of these decisions of the Member States without budgetary responsibility. Yes, we must vote for this exceptional aid, but the best way to help Greece in a sustainable way is to cancel some of this unsustainable and incondictable debt.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, at a time when the troika has turned Greece into a social graveyard, the European Commission has finally decided to amend Regulation 1303 of 2013 on the Structural Funds in order to address the liquidity problems and lack of available resources facing Greece, due to the memoranda that imposed a violent fiscal adjustment and reduced public investment. However, even this is not done unconditionally by the European Union, as it accompanies it: 1) with the indefamenable application of Memorandum 3, which imposes tough measures amounting to EUR 13 billion. (2) with the plundering of public property amounting to EUR 50 billion. (3) with the refugee crisis. Lenders are therefore handing out Greece's cloths in order to allow the unimpeded financing of the NSRF. Thus, with one hand the European Union gives funds to the NSRF, which Greece is entitled to anyway, and with the other hand takes them back double and triple. Moreover, according to European Commission data, more than 40% of the European funds allocated to Greece go directly back to the hard core countries of the European Union, such as the Netherlands, for the purchase of industrial equipment, raw materials, consumer goods and so on. For this reason, European funds must be invested in productive investment, in the primary sector, in new technologies, in infrastructure, in industrial development and in tourism. And certainly not in consumption and imports. The funded actions of the NSRF should focus on investments in sectors that bring domestic added value to Greece. But in order for Greece to enter the avenue of new development, it must throw the troika out of the country and get rid of the burden of shameful debt that must be written off.  Finally, I would like to point out to my colleague from Bulgaria that in Greece there is no Turkish minority, but a religious, Muslim minority, which enjoys its rights unhindered, unlike the Greek minority in Istanbul and other parts of Turkey, which is being severely oppressed by the Turkish authorities.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Madam President, the Commission's proposal gives a little relief to my country, Greece and the Greek people, who have been suffering for years from a great recession, high unemployment, great poverty and a huge reduction in investment. And it is good that almost all of the political groups, with the exception of the eurogroup of the extreme right, support this process.  With the Commission's proposal, approved by the European Parliament, my country will not get a single euro more than the Community budget, it will only facilitate investment at last. And the Tsipras government's plan is $100 billion. investments in the coming years, not only public, but also private, and many reforms to combat tax evasion, corruption, the client state . But tomorrow we need to adopt this proposal as it is, and that is why I want to say that the amendments that Mrs Le Pen's Eurogroup hypocritically tabled are not for the good of the Greek people. If approved, it will be to stop this positive process.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: – Madam President, of course we all feel for the Greek people. What is going on there is terrible for the people of Greece. They are not to blame for the situation at all. We have been told Greece is in dire need of help and is suffering economic disaster. Well, as Basil Fawlty would say, ‘specialised subject: the bleeding obvious’. The measures to help pass through the committee came through with very little debate or democratic scrutiny at all. They passed through easily and smoothly to come to this place. I am concerned by some of them, and I suggest that the Greeks should remember the words of President Reagan when he said – and I paraphrase badly – that ‘I am from the government and I am here to help’ are the most frightening words in the English language. I would suggest that ‘I am from the EU and here to help’ are perhaps the most terrifying words in the English language. Help never comes without strings and it is never straightforward. The Greek state reminds me very much of my uncle. He is a great chap, a likeable, top person, but he always needs and wants more than he can actually afford at the time, so he ends up asking for his money and his wages frontloaded. He never deals with the real problem, which is that he spends too much on beer and cigarettes. The Greek state should deal with the real problem. They should begin by leaving the eurozone: that is the obvious way forward for them. What will happen when other countries within the eurozone see what happens here, see this precedent and demand any funds to them to be frontloaded? It is unsustainable. Maybe we should appoint Basil Fawlty as an EU Commissioner and perhaps he can then point out the ‘bleeding obvious’ and we can get some common sense in this place.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has Greece is certainly being affected in an extraordinary way by the financial crisis. Athens lacks the funds for public investment, it has massive liquidity problems. Of course, in the past, European structural and investment funds have played a major role in attracting investment in Greece – after all, 25% of the investment comes from these funds. The Commission has therefore proposed a rapid procedure to improve the liquidity situation and boost investment in the context of the framework for the third Greek package. The rapporteur for this report has endorsed these proposals to amend the regulation and calls for additional advances from the 2014-2020 budget framework for the operational programmes of the cohesion policy and the Maritime and Fisheries Fund, the so-called frontloading. Secondly, it calls for a 100% increase in the cap on cumulative pre-financing and interim payments for programmes for the period 2013-2017 under the Convergence and Regional Competitiveness objectives – that is, a lifting of the ceiling on payments from these programmes. The lifting of the need for co-financing and the dropping of a ceiling are intended to enable an additional EUR 2 billion for investment in the Greek budget. In other words, the Greek budget can save these two billion. The Committee on Budgets in this Parliament has confirmed that the implementation of the programme before 2016 is important – as has already been said today – otherwise not only five per cent, but at the end of the day, 95 per cent of pre-financing would have to be repaid. That is why it is important that success is checked and that there should be a permanent rapporteur in the Committee on Regional Policy on cofinancing. I therefore call on the Greek Prime Minister, in addition to these measures, to make something of it. Create framework conditions in your country that promote implementation, release of investments, and create additional employment! Otherwise, this expression of solidarity is in vain.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Madam President, the harsh austerity measures imposed on Greece over the last 5 years have impoverished the Greek people, dramatically increased the unemployment rate, especially among young people, and generally destroyed the economic and social fabric of the country. With this in view of this, the proposal of the Committee on Regional Development to take measures on growth and investment in Greece is encouraging. But there are some questions: a. How can there be investments and jobs in Greece when there is no growth in the primary sector because there are no funds available to it? b. How will poverty be combated and the living conditions of the Greek people improved when the implementation of the measures of the Memorandums has also absorbed the last euro of the Greek worker? c. How will youth unemployment be combated when there are no jobs and the money allocated to them is consumed and made available to various companies that teach them things, which it is doubtful whether they will use and need? Finally, how is it possible for young people in Greece to find work when hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants flock to Greece from third countries, including "talented young people", as Mr Juncker said, who also have to find work. In order for the programme to succeed, the money must be allocated to the sectors in which it is needed and must be made available, especially in the primary sector, and the wages to be given to Greeks are not hunger wages and wages of workers from third world countries.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Madam President, we welcome and support this aid to Greece and to the Greek people, even if this is clearly not the aid that the Greek people might have expected or expected, but it is particularly important and I will also welcome the statement by the Vice-Commissioner, Mr Dombrovskis, who said that 'we have the means and with all our strength we will fight to support programmes for the Greek people and Greece'.  You are well aware that the one who has suffered the worst in recent years as a result of the economic crisis, and I am not going to examine the causes of this crisis, is the Greek people, and continues to be in this difficult position today. We must all, not only in a show of solidarity, but because this must come first for the European Union, if it is really considered a Union, to support and support a people within it who are being tested hard, such as Greece. I believe that the two billion will enable this money to be used for growth and the creation of new jobs. It is important to hit the unemployment that exists in Greece, but also in other countries, such as Cyprus, Portugal and Spain, which have suffered this kind of economic crisis and must activate these programmes rapidly towards these countries, with oversipled procedures defeating the invincible bureaucracy of Brussels. It is also the responsibility of the European Union to achieve these programmes; In conclusion, however, I cannot leave unnoticed what Mr Torvalds, who I hope is out of ignorance and only out of ignorance, that is to say, referring to a Turkish minority. This is an unspeakable, unrealistic attitude that has nothing to do with reality. In Greece there is only a religious Muslim minority, which enjoys all rights. It is Hellenism, the Asia Minor, the Pontian and the Constantinople, which has been persecuted by the Turks and not the religious minority in Greece.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: – Madam President, decisions such as the one we are going to take tomorrow — quick and urgent decisions, overcoming barriers and obstacles, as in the past plenary in relation to refugees — also serve to bring Europe back to hope in the people. I always say that if Europe does not generate hope in people, people will definitely lose hope in Europe. And, of course, austerity thwarted many hopes and many expectations. And, as a result of extreme austerity, we also have extreme decisions, extreme complicated situations to which we have to respond, because responding we are talking about people, ways of life, employment, companies, the dynamization of the economy to generate economic activity, a new perspective and a new horizon. It is right that the European Parliament meets the demands. It is right that the European Parliament will quickly and urgently amend a regulation, and that it does so precisely to solve situations and generate that economic activity in order to restore that hope. To give that hope back to the Greeks and, ultimately, to the Europeans, to make Europe more just, more supportive, something that cares about people, their problems and their citizens.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her There is no question that we need to help Greece. Greece has also been helped a lot. If we remember, the last multiannual financial framework provided EUR 42 billion in funding for Greece. And the subsidy rate has been increased from the usual 85% to 95%. This 10% addition is eur 4 billion. And yet Greece was unable to get two billion euros from these funds. This was partly due to the fact that the Greek administration was unable to meet all the requirements. What conclusions do we draw from this? Firstly, we are now increasing the EU's co-financing to 100%. In addition, these funds can now be called up early before all the necessary documents are submitted. It is also open to appropriations earmarked for later financial years. But I wonder: is this really the right medicine for this unfortunately sick patient? I think no! For one thing, we have a distortion of facts here – we are talking here about cofinancing the EU, but in reality it is full funding. Full financing, however, is always a strategic risk, because if a recipient of grants no longer has to provide their own services, the risk of no meaningful investments increases enormously. In addition, we must finally improve the administration in Greece so that the funds – which are available – can also be used in a meaningful way. Finally, what about the sustainability of these funds if we are now spending funds in the next one or two years that are actually intended for a seven-year period? None of this can work. That is why we are convinced that this is not the right medicine. Instead, we must finally face the truth: Greece is over-indebted and needs a 50% debt cut and must be released from the eurozone.

name: Martina MICHELS
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We have before us a sensible, unbureaucratic proposal, which we can only agree to. And yet it is wrong for some of my fellow Members to pretend that they are dealing with gifts to Greece. Rather, it is a sensible correction of our own procurement directives, some of which are ineffective. If this access prove successful, it could later benefit other economically weak Member States in the same way. An EU support policy that follows the logic of rapid success rates and increasingly focuses on private investment will not be successful in the long term. Cohesion policy should finally function as a solidarity redistribution mechanism, rather than following questionable macroeconomic conditioning – a conditioning that is itself the cause of economic and political crises.

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for We shall make one thing clear immediately: there is no European money. It is tax money from hard-working citizens that is at stake in Greece. Recently, Greece agreed to raise its retirement age to 67. Until now, Greece has had a list of as many as 580 different professions that were considered dangerous or exhausting. If you worked in one of these professions, you could retire as early as the age of 50. I note that the TV presenter was part of the professions that were considered dangerous. Laughable and intimidating! At the same time, my country, Sweden, is having discussions about raising the retirement age to 75 years. It is telling what a sick organisation the EU is when money is taken from taxpayers in some Member States and given to not quite as diligent taxpayers in other Member States. It is time to stop giving artificial respiration to Greece at the taxpayers' expense. Instead, let the Greeks leave the euro area, return to the drachma, devalue and get themselves back on their feet.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: Ladies and gentlemen, I repeat, it cannot be repeated enough: what you are doing in the context of the rescue of your single currency, which you are doing in the context of keeping the Greeks on board, is nothing less than the creation of a political unity economy in which the Member States and the peoples of Europe are slowly but surely , step by step, again today, will be denied the power to draw out and shape their own socio-economic future. The peoples of Europe are gradually sliding into a situation in which their investments, their pensions, their budgets and their infrastructure will be defined and streamlined here in the temples of the European Union. What the peoples of Europe must learn to understand is that this European Union is crushing the diversity of the peoples of Europe under the guise of supposedly necessary structural reforms for the stability of a failed currency. What the European Union is doing is essentially deactiving the democracy of the free peoples. Stop this! That is our message today, not only to the Greeks but to all the peoples of Europe.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – The question is whether this EU money will help the Greek economy and the Greek people in a very difficult situation to recover. And the answer is the same as in other peripheral countries, in particular, that it depends on it. It depends on the procedures, the decision-making mechanisms in which these funds are distributed and to whom these funds are allocated. If it gets access to fair and transparent procedures, decent Greek small businesses, medium-sized entrepreneurs, smallholders, and public money will serve the common good – say, improving the situation in Greek health – then yes, this money will help us to recover. However, if what happens, as in my own country, with a lot of EU money and resources, is that corrupt decision-makers put these money in the hands of oligarchs who are intertred with politics, it will not help us to recover. And I would like to stress that, just as in Hungary, as with regard to EU land-based subsidies, the European Union would have a duty to examine whether money is distributed in fair and transparent procedures, as in Greece, with regard to these funds.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: – Madam President, I would like to greet all my colleagues, all my colleagues, to greet the Commissioner and congratulate the Commission on this proposal - a proposal that reinforces solidarity - but the budgetary solidarity of the European Union is something that has existed for many dozens of years. I would remind you that the European Social Fund has even existed since 1958. But it is a strengthening of solidarity that will relieve Greece, which has financial difficulties, a difficulty in liquidity, and will therefore be able to use the funds with less financial effort on its part. This less financial effort, this strengthening of solidarity, requires greater vigilance, requires additional responsibility. The amounts to 100% co-financing, the pre-financing rates amount to about EUR 2 billion, require that these amounts be used in projects that are sustainable. We want smart solidarity that contributes to Greece's growth, which contributes to strengthening Greece's competitiveness, bringing more jobs, and therefore these funds, in addition to social cohesion, in addition to economic cohesion, should also bring greater wealth to the European Union, greater wealth for Greece, and hopefully we are convinced that Greece , the Greek authorities, have an opportunity here that they cannot waste. Once again we show solidarity and ask that Greece, the authorities, are also up to our solidarity.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would also like to thank Mrs Mihaylova for her report and for the speed with which she has guided our committee's decision.  It is well known that, as a result of the crisis, investment levels have plummeted throughout Europe, both private and public, when it would have been necessary to intervene and revive the economy with specific funds for growth and innovation. In this situation, cohesion policy has remained, even and above all in these more difficult years, the most substantial and concrete source of investment for European citizens.  We also know that the situation in Greece, despite the efforts made on the road to reform, remains difficult. , and make it possible to accelerate resource spending in the first period. This is very important because it shows us that a more flexible use of the Structural Funds can enable countries to improve their investment performance.  I wanted to remind the many Colleagues who keep saying nonsense that the European Union with its entire budget costs the citizens of Europe three days in taxes, the rest is their ... (The President withdrew the floor from the speaker).

name: Edward CZESAK
text: – Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. We are aware that the financial crisis will lead to permanently negative growth rates in Greece and to serious liquidity problems and a lack of public funds for the necessary investments to boost growth and job creation. The European Commission's next plan for Greece – this time in the form of the release of the last 5% of payments from the European Union budget until the programmes are closed and the maximum co-financing rate increased to 100%, as well as the provision of additional initial advances for 2015 and 2016 – only confirms the mobilisation of the Union and its readiness to help a member of the Union in crisis. However, I would like to remind the European Commission that cohesion policy is first and foremost the European Union's largest investment policy, not a financial lifeline for countries at risk of bankruptcy. Therefore, any action taken through cohesion policy mechanisms must not have consequences, either now or in the future, and in particular the budgetary implications, for the beneficiary countries of that policy. The solutions proposed must be absolutely extraordinary, exceptional and, above all, one-off. We therefore expect the European Commission to make a clear declaration and ensure that the new specific measures for Greece do not have negative consequences for payments to other countries, are not used as an argument in the forthcoming review and negotiations on the Multiannual Financial Framework and do not create congestion in payments.

name: Nikolaos CHOUNTIS
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the amendment of problematic and anti-development regulation 1303/2013 for Greece was decided on 12 July, when the Greek Government signed the third memorandum, a memorandum with the same destructive and anti-development logic as the others, which is silenced by the European Commission's report.  How we got to this point: I would remind you that until the signing of the third memorandum the European Commission, illegally and arbitrarily, deprived the Greek government, the Greek economy of all forms of financing, thus depriving the public and private investors of resources and delaying the implementation of the projects. Today, Mr Vice-President, and I am speaking today with Commissioner Cređu in Greece, it seems that the request for an extension is being rejected so that the projects of the previous period can be completed, and at the same time this amendment to the regulation, which is in fact the product of blackmail, appears as an expression of solidarity. Ladies and gentlemen, the problem of cohesion policy is not being implemented with such policies and this concerns all countries. It is therefore necessary for the Community to demonstrate a genuine policy of cohesion and convergence of economies and societies.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I would first like to congratulate the rapporteur on the work on the dossier. I can say that I know the situation in Greece so much that I can form my opinion on this. I am sure that the difficult times the Greek people are going through require extraordinary measures. Emergencies, of course, require such extraordinary reactions on our part. However, these emergencies also require extraordinary control. Extraordinary control over every cent of the European taxpayer going to Greece, because if there is one thing I do not believe in, it is that I fully believe in the government that is currently standing in Greece. I also don't trust Mr Tsipras, who said he was firmly behind the European Union just two days before he went to ask Russia for help. I do not believe the same Mr Tsipras, who has said he will fully honour the commitments made to the Greek people, will hold his responsibility until the end exactly one month before he resigns. So I would like to call on you, in addition to the vote on these extraordinary measures for Greece, given that there are 27 other Member States in the European Union, to have one in mind, to closely monitor the situation there and the spending of European funds against the plan we are adopting today, so as to ensure that all people in Europe that their money is spent in the most transparent way possible so that we can get Greece back on its feet.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we welcomed the package of measures that Commissioner Crețu has proposed in support of Greece and we thank President Mihaylova for her valuable work.  By definition, cohesion policy must be firmly rooted in the territories and regions in which it affects. The Structural Funds and the rules that accompany their use must be able to operate effectively in the contexts in which they are committed; the liquidity problems which are holding back investment in Greece and which have made these exceptional measures necessary are of a seriousness which we all hope will be temporary and we hope that, also thanks to these measures, cohesion policy will achieve its objectives, reduce the gap between regions and enable the Greek regions to grow.  Although the measures taken by the Commission are exceptional, the conditions which made them necessary are not an isolated case. There are other regions which face the same difficulties, although not as seriously as they would require similar action; Let us not tire of repeating that southern Italy too – with which the Commissioner is well aware and I thank her personally for the attention she has given us together with the regions of the Mezzogiorno – is suffering from the cofinancing rules and is calling for greater flexibility. I hope that the path mapped out by the Greek case will lead us to a serious reflection on the future of cohesion policy, its financing, but above all its effectiveness. We must identify the obstacles and remove them.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her A previous speaker said that the citizens do not understand what we are talking about here today. I wonder what the citizens would say if they understood what we are deciding today. When I look into this impressively empty Parliament, I sometimes wonder whether the decision is actually being placed in this Parliament, so that the citizens do not even know what is being decided. Today, we decide that Greece can claim funds – eur 35 billion, after all, without adding a single cent of cofinancing – immediately, stante pede; what was saved for several years in the context of medium-term financial planning, the Greeks should now be able to spend everything at once. One can imagine that this will of course be done with full hands, because it costs you nothing. No more co-financing is required. And if all the money is spent quickly, then the projects that you have to select so quickly will hardly be particularly good. I believe that we are being very irresponsible in our handling of the tax penny of our citizens.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: Madam President, these measures announced are in the right direction and at the same time are also a remedy for the disastrous policies implemented in Greece, but also for the fact that all these stereotypes and racist attacks that Greece has been attacked and unfortunately I have heard some of your colleagues, shame on you, repeat the same thing today, for the corrupt, for pensioners. , for all this. Don't you understand that if you put the Jews in the place of the Greek, you reach other situations and go to other times?  Greece needs more help, as do other countries in the south of Europe that are in trouble and need help, too, because we have the refugee problem that is too big and also because it needs restructuring its debt. And as for the funds, fear not, the current government will make the best use of them. It does not do like previous governments, your allies, many times. He will use them with dignity, honesty and meritocracy.

name: Ingeborg GRÄSSLE
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Nothing is good in Greece. The Committee on Budgetary Control was there last week and visited seven projects from the 181 projects priority list. Above all, we have found a lack of money. The question is: where does the lack of money come from? It comes naturally from the fact that projects have been financed for many years. Fourteen years. Now the end of the flagpole has been reached. The question, Mr Vice-President, is, what are we doing with all the ruins of investment? The Commission's draft is a draft that does not help, which does not really solve the problems, because the problems are, of course, elsewhere. And it would be nice, dear Greek colleagues, if Greece were also to help itself. We have seen that there are major problems with land expropriations – long-standing procedures. Why are we not taking measures to shorten these procedures? Then we would have faster and better investments. Why, please, are decisions not made in such a way that those who have to make the decisions in the projects – namely the project managers – are allowed to make decisions? The government, like its predecessors, still takes everything to itself and does not want to decide. It would be nice if the Commission had presented which projects from the 2007 to 2013 list should now be financed. I would like to warn as a matter of urgency against continuing in Greece as it has been so far. The future selection of projects must be much sharper and much more thoughtfully, otherwise we will again be confronted with investment ruins at the end of the next period, where we will then consider which and how much money will have to be repaid. I consider what has been presented today to be a breach of the law and a serious error. I see that there is a broad consensus here according to the motto: a lot helps a lot. But it will not help. Let us at least learn from the past and avoid the worst mistakes for the future. However, this requires considerable rework from the EU Commission, especially with regard to the current status of the project and future project selection. If it just goes on like this, then really good night! (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: "blue card" question. – Mrs Gräßle, from what you have said, if I understand correctly, you disagree with the positive attitude of the European People's Party, supporting this proposal. Do I get it right? Are you against the positive attitude of the European People's Party?  And secondly: The European Parliament delegation, which went to Athens and inspected the progress of some projects, found long delays for these projects, which relate to the period when New Democracy and PASOK were governed. Why don't you mention that? How long are we going to see the issues with colored spectacles of partisan expediency?

name: Ingeborg GRÄSSLE
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I will not, in fact, vote in favour tomorrow, because I do not think it is expedient and a mistake, because it will increase the current problems in the future. I have to tell you that, as a budgetary controller, I do not really care who has been stunned. I just want it to get better. But I do not see it getting any better now, and I see it with great regret. It must be better, and it would be in the primary interest of the Greeks themselves. So: Please, help! Thank you!

name: Giorgos GRAMMATIKAKIS
text: Madam President, I think that the Commission's proposal and tomorrow's urgent vote are in the realms of the obvious, because Europe is, at last, obliged to show solidarity with Greece and indeed to extend this solidarity which has been the cornerstone of its creation on other issues and on other countries; In fact, a colleague discovered the Turkish minority in Greece, perhaps confused them with the discovery of current waters on the planet Mars. We are tired, ladies and gentlemen, of the Greek people being accused, at a time when scandals are developing in powerful countries, that they are corrupt, that they are enslaved to interests, that they only have interests behind the surface. I insist on the positive side of this story and of course the Greek government, recently elected, has a great responsibility. Because this aid must not become an end in it to it. I hope that the Greek Government will understand that this small aid, the economic aid, must be the beginning of a much larger effort to correct all the bad texts in my country and, I regret to say, many times in your own countries.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Speaking in the debate on specific measures for Greece, I would like to express my hope that both raising the maximum co-financing rate for Greek programmes from the 2007-2013 perspective to 100% and increasing pre-financing for programmes implemented from the current perspective will be another important instrument to support the Union's entry into the path of sustainable economic growth. Such exceptional arrangements should result, on the one hand, in the concentration of European funds transferred to Greece of more than EUR 2 billion, while, on the other hand, the application of a maximum co-financing rate of 100% should result in savings in Greek budgetary expenditure of EUR 2 billion. In doing so, I would like to express my hope that this financial effort in the Union budget will not be wasted by the Greek authorities, but that 100% financing of projects by the Union unfortunately creates such a danger. I also believe that the concentration of more than EUR 2 billion in payments to Greece should be fully compensated by the end of the current financial framework and should therefore be neutral for the multiannual budget for the period 2014-2020.

name: Jan OLBRYCHT
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Dear! The discussion we are discussing is neither a normal matter nor a policy change issue. We are dealing today with a conversation about the emergency situation: we are amending the regulations, changing the way we finance. And this is very much a consequence of serious surgery.  Firstly, it is undoubtedly a kind of response to an emergency situation, in other words, a statement that a change of approach is needed – the question is whether there is a long-term change or some short-term action that concerns a particular situation. We are changing certain rules for a limited period of time, because shared management also requires shared funding. At a time when we are giving up shared funding, we are dealing with management that is only partially shared. We must therefore realise that this is an emergency situation, that this is an emergency aid situation, but it can have consequences if it can happen, that it will also apply to other countries where certain rules will have to be changed. This is a matter of precedent. I, of course, support this type of treatment, but as a financial support for Greece, not a change in cohesion policy.

name: Louis-Joseph MANSCOUR
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, if those who, and there are many of them, I see in this Chamber, wished to sacrifice the Greeks on the altar of their national public opinion and political revenge had won their bet, it is humanitarian aid that we would be discussing today. However, since the Grexit scenario was buried by the agreement last July, it is fortunately on the basis of the European Structural Funds that we are now considering helping the Greek economy to regain its colours.  Let no one doubt that the third aid plan for Greece will only be used for the service of public debt and the recapitalization of the Greek banks. Therefore, facilitating the use of the European Structural Funds is vital, as the need, as has been said, for liquidity is sorely felt, to revive an economy that the efforts of the previous aid plan have made exhausted.  So this proposal is going in the right direction, but it will not be enough. The renegotiation of Greece's debt and the construction of a stronger and more democratic economic and monetary union are two prerequisites for the country's recovery and the management of future crises.  In inviting the President of the Republic, François Hollande, and Chancellor Merkel to speak here on Wednesday in front of Parliament, President Schulz understood the importance of the issues that the Greek episode revealed. We expect them, therefore, to breathe new life into the challenges that are just as crucial as those we faced a quarter of a century ago when the Iron Curtain fell.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Greece and no end.
