So the EU Commission now wants to pay even more money and even faster money from EU funds to Greece – in addition to the many hundreds of lost bailout billions. Firstly, this is a waste of money. Since the introduction of the euro, Greece has already received 58 billion net from the EU budget. Again: not as a bailout billion, but as a net profiteer. Nevertheless: everything in vain. Greece is now closer to the level of the Third World than to that of the first. Secondly, the investment programme does not make economic sense; it's wrong. Greece does not lack investment, but Greece lacks reforms that make investment attractive. There is a reason why no investment is being made in Greece. Thirdly, Greece is insolvent. Greece no longer helps to leave the euro, or it would help, but it does not come. That is why Germany must step down.

name: Georgios KYRTSOS
text: Madam President, I think the European Commission's initiative supported by the political groups is in the right direction. Additional liquidity is provided to the Greek economy, at a time when it is threatened, due to the wrong manipulations made in 2015, by a lack of bank financing and a return to recession. Financial facilities will not work unless the policy implemented and the banking system works effectively. Between January and August 2015, Greek banks lost deposits of 40 billion euros, a quarter of the total, due to failed economic experiments by the Radical Left. Without a climate of confidence and without a massive return of deposits, businesses that want to take part in the European programmes to which we are referring will not be able to finance adequately by the banking sector.  Many of these programmes are related to the support of enterprises in the tourism sector. The Greek government increases the VAT levied on catering, but also the VAT levied on hotel accommodation. On the one hand, we are loading taxes on an industry on which the development of the Greek economy can be based and on the other hand we are trying to finance tourism businesses with European funds. The more favourable financing of Greece by the European Union and, of course, the taxpayers of the European Union, is an essential act of solidarity which, however, does not solve the problem. It simply offers time to improve the economic policy applied in Greece.

name: Miltiadis KYRKOS
text: Madam President, the co-financing of the projects of the previous period and the pre-financing of the new projects are very important for Greece. And they are important and we see them as a sign that the European side is reaching out for solidarity, supporting the July agreement. The support of an agreement made with the Greek government that accepted and embraced a series of reforms that are pending five, ten or even twenty years. After the Greek government wandered into the desert of out-of-euro versions outside Europe, he actually landed, said he was embracing reforms and promised to work with the European side. We see this one side of this cooperation, I hope we will see it tomorrow, with the adoption of the proposal. But there is another side, one that the Greek Government itself has put in place, a tool that will be able to help make the evaluation procedures, from the single support mechanism, open to the European peoples, through the European Parliament and the Conference of Presidents has already accepted, and Mr Schulz has already taken it up and is already working with Mr Juncker on how our Parliament can participate. , be a tool that may not let things that have been denounced in the past for unnecessary and new demands be done, but at the same time impose, control and help support the reforms that Greece needs.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – Allow me to begin by saying, and at the same time, congratulating both the Commissioner, Mr Dombrovskis, and Mrs Mikhail for the suggestion that such a proposal is in Parliament and that we also accept it under an expedited procedure. Greece is in a major crisis. In fact, the first half of this year was only about whether the Greek economy would fall or if Greece would even leave the European Community or be excluded from the euro zone or exit the eurozone on its own. The stubbornness of the former finance minister and also Mr Cipras has taken this even so far that the start of the tourist season in Greece has been marked by closed banks, which we have seen to be a major problem and has major implications for the Greek economy. I am therefore pleased that a third memorandum has been adopted, which also includes this measure, to help Greece carry out cohesion projects. We know that cohesion projects are one of the key tools of solidarity within the European Union and that Greece has major difficulties in completing, financing cohesion projects, so this aid of two billion, which goes in this direction, that projects can be 100 per cent co-financed on the one hand, on the other hand, for advancepayments, is a very concrete step to help Greece in these difficult, difficult times. It is important that the funds are used correctly. When they have the resources... when projects have 10 per cent co-financing, when projects also have an advance payment, there are also very many temptations, traps for various irregularities, malvers that, as we all know, have also happened in Greece in the past. I therefore think that there are very warnings in place from those who are concerned about public spending, and I hope that these funds will be really well spent and that they will have an impact on the economy, for new jobs, because only then will Greece get out of the crisis.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: – Mr President, Commissioner and ladies and gentlemen, austerity policies have had terrible impacts on the lives of people, families, businesses and countries intervened by the troika. There is no country that, in seeking such help, has not been a victim of its own family. I am referring here to the European family. And when I say "so-called help, " it's because it's just that: pretense. Austerity has failed, austerity has only created more misery, poverty, more bankruptcies, fears, more immigration, flight from senior staff, depressions and suicides. We're talking about people, we're not talking about numbers.  When I tell you this, it seems like I'm describing my country, Portugal. We felt, in Portugal, for four years, the hardness of being a minor son of Europe. Greece has been severely punished by years of austerity. In addition to this, hundreds of refugees arrive in Greece every day and we almost demand that Greece deal with the matter on its own. Greece is asking us for real help. This is the means of adopting specific support measures through the European funds. These measures are a possibility of investment and austerity relief. It is not about giving Greece more money, it is about anticipating such funding, it is about promoting growth and jobs. We know that cohesion policies are fundamental for the countries that have been hit hardest by the crisis. Without cohesion policies everything would be further aggravated. Some question whether this money will be well spent, but in the same way that there was technical assistance for austerity, of course there should also be such assistance for investment.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: – Madam President, it has often been said and it was said again today that the EU is based on solidarity, or at least it should be. The economic and financial situation Greece faced gave the EU an opportunity to show such solidarity, and unfortunately it took a long time before the EU stepped up to the plate and took any action. Indeed, I would say maybe the lack of action by the EU has made the problems in Greece even worse. Even with a new agreement in place now, I still think Greece faces huge problems in the future in terms of its economy. Also, of course, it now faces a refugee crisis too. Greece, like other Member States, is facing a huge burden and I would say that perhaps the best way – or one of the best ways – the European Union can help countries like Greece is through the European structural funds. The structural funds should be going to improve the economy and the prosperity of places like Greece. I would also hope that the structural funds could be used to alleviate the problems due to the refugee crisis by helping with funding for infrastructure and social inclusion measures as well. I am pleased that the EU Commissioner, Commissioner Crețu, seems open to that idea in the future. I would hope that tomorrow we would help to support Greece. Greece needs that help now. It is no good providing this funding sometime in the distant future: we need to provide help and investment to Greece as soon as possible. I support the measures put forward by the Commission. I support this Parliament and the Council taking speedy action to put those measures in place, and I hope tomorrow all colleagues – or as many colleagues as possible – will support these measures to help Greece.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: – Mr President, this proposal is welcome, given the social emergency experienced by the Greek people. We recall that this situation stems from decades of austerity, with the imposition of interference and external intervention programs. They are policies designed to secure the profits of the major economic groups and the great European finance, and that have been bleeding the Greek people, leaving them poorer, more dependent and tied to an unsustainable and unjust debt. This help is thus positive and may alleviate the suffering of many people. However, it is only a palliative. In this sense, it is urgent that basic measures be taken to restore the Greek economy on sound foundations and in accordance with the will of the Greek people. The situation in Greece confirms our analysis based on the reality of Portugal. There is an urgent need to open up a negotiating process for renegotiating sovereign debt at European Union level, as well as an intergovernmental conference that will review the budgetary treaty and eliminate the monetary gap that gives any possibility of alternative and sovereign development.

name: Manolis KEFALOGIANNIS
text: Madam President, they say that the European Union is an organisation that always takes two steps forward and one step back. In the case of Greece, it has made a leap forward. A leap for a country that is more affected than any other by the crisis that the whole of southern Europe has experienced. That is why I would particularly like to thank the European Commission, Mr Juncker, the Vice-President-in-Office, Mr Dombrovskis, the European Council, the European Parliament's committees on the budget, employment and fisheries, all the political forces of the European Parliament and the vast majority of my fellow Members in the European Parliament.  Help, really, is valuable. Aid for Greece, from the European Funds, is more than valuable, for a country that has huge problems and huge liquidity problems. A country that wants, seeks and sees solidarity, from partners in the European Union, at a difficult economic juncture, all the more so now that it is welcoming hundreds of thousands of migrants and refugees.  And something about my colleague from Bulgaria, Mr Torvalds: The 1923 Lausanne Treaty speaks of a Muslim minority, and his own country has voted for it. A country that oppresses a minority is a country that does not elect three Muslim MPs in Komotini.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to claim the value of the decision we are taking, both in the direction of a more marked show of solidarity, especially budgetary solidarity, of Europe's resources and also, shall we say, of opening up a confrontation that goes beyond the austerity policies that have accompanied recent years and which have also profoundly marked the fate of a country such as Greece.  I would, however, like to take this opportunity to highlight here too a proposal which goes in the direction of a mechanism for the solidarity of cohesion policy. We are at the end of the long 2007-2013 programming cycle of cohesion policy resources and it is likely and we will do everything, we are all committed to avoiding the disengagement of huge resources. I believe, however, that we must consider the possibility that if all of us were to have the opportunity to have a large budget of resources disengaged in programming, to use these resources to concentrate them and to deal with the most serious humanitarian crisis we face, that of refugees, and therefore to use the disengagement not to return resources to cohesion policy to the individual States. , but to put them back at the service of a fund that must make a great effort to deal with this enormous crisis that lies before us.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – So the crisis that has ravaged Greece in recent years has, of course, left many consequences. Some quite fatal to the people of Greece. And even in times of crisis, in the European... quite a few money was flowing into the Greek register. Of course, the main problem arises as to why this money was spent, for which needs. And at times it seemed as if bank recovery took precedence over the interests and needs of citizens. I hope that this attitude will change in the future and that the funds earmarked for this third plan will in fact also be spent on those key purposes in cohesion, social and regional funds. It is true, however, that Greece, on the other hand, must also contribute its part, particularly in some key, including evidentiary reforms. I would like to draw attention here, in particular, to the problem of the cadastre, because without the regulated data on the land register, of course also in investments, especially in infrastructure, there can be problems.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I would like to say that I consider these measures to be exceptional, to be exceptional, and also from the point of view of the exceptional times at which they take place. On the one hand, the irresponsible behaviour of the Greek Government, which undoubtedly has its share of responsibility, is very fundamental for what the economic situation in Greece is now. But also how much time has been wasted in that time, when it could already be dealt with in a positive way. I think that we cannot even drown the trust of European taxpayers. I am not entirely sure that the positive measures that we are supposed to support here are sufficiently conditional on the future period, that is, whether the European taxpayer will really be the last in line to see any result again. However, I want to show solidarity with the Greek people and i therefore consider it necessary to support the proposed measures.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, considering the fact that Greece has been very much affected by the consequences of the financial and economic crisis, that it faces a critical lack of public funds and consequently has difficulties in co-financing the investments of the European Structural and Investment Funds, I strongly support the proposal to provide additional pre-financing in the current financial period, as well as to increase the co-financing rate for the 2014-2020 operational programmes.  In view of the urgency of the need for support in Greece, I also welcome the agreement within the political groups on the necessity of the introduction of a simplified procedure. Greece is part of the European architecture and it has to stay that way.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the wave of instability and the widespread concerns that the recent Greek crisis has brought to the whole Mediterranean scenario have not ended their negative influences and, although the danger of default – or so hopefully – the long-term remedies have faded, they must be implemented in a comprehensive, generalised and rapid manner.  This text shows that the stage of emergency choices has not been exhausted and that Greece still needs extraordinary support measures because it cannot afford to lose cohesion policy funding with you. There is a widespread perception of the fragility of the euro area economy and all the institutions have been called upon to be part of them with the finding of every economic resource still available and the same balance that, with a gesture of responsibility and foresight, I would ask for to be implemented even for southern Italy, so lacking in resources but now so ready to take advantage of every opportunity for redemption.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all thank you for this debate, from which I actually sense quite broad support for the Commission’s proposal. Indeed, EU funds have made a major contribution to strengthening Greece’s economy and social and territorial cohesion. But now the investment co-financed with EU funds is being held back by the Greek state’s tight liquidity situation, and also the generally very difficult state of the Greek economy. So this is a unique situation and the measures proposed are exceptional. Once again, I would like to thank the co-legislators for moving ahead speedily with this file, because time is indeed of the essence for the success of this proposal. The eligibility date for expenditure under the 2007-2013 programmes is imminent: the end of this year. Without these extraordinary measures many already well-advanced investments would be at risk of being forgotten. Turning to some of the questions which were raised regarding this proposal: on the consequences for other cohesion states, I must ensure that there are no negative consequences for other Member States in terms of payments, and the Commission would by no means make any arguments in this regard in a mid-term review. As I outlined in my introductory remarks, this proposal is budget-neutral under the current Multiannual Financial Framework period.

name: Iskra MIHAYLOVA
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, thank you to all the colleagues who took part in the debate, Commissioner, thank you also for your clarification. The debate was very interesting and very focused on the problems of both Greece and cohesion policy.  Allow me to make a few clarifications and respond to some of the lines that were presented here in the hall. First, I would like to point out that the Committee on Regional Policy very responsibly examined the European Commission's proposal at two meetings of its own, dedicated a special extraordinary meeting and then held another meeting where it discussed the issue. I accept all the considerations of colleagues who fear a possible lack of control. I would like to stress that this proposal does not give Greece a gift, this proposal enables the Greek side to use resources when it needs it, at a time when it needs this resource.  This proposal is extraordinary, requires extraordinary behaviour and extraordinary measures, but it does not set a precedent and does not increase funding for the Greek side, but allows Greece to use a resource that has already been agreed to be able to solve problems at the moment. Cohesion policy does not become a financial liquidity policy, cohesion policy through this type of emergency solutions fulfils its role to be effectively implemented under the conditions in each Member State. Whether the measures will be successful, we will see, monitor and control. Cohesion policy through such initiatives and such a measure enables the Greek government. Whether it will use this opportunity, we will be able to control through the reports to the European Commission and through all the European Parliament's control tools.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 6 October 2015. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – In view of greece's exceptional economic circumstances, I support the Commission's proposal for specific measures for Greece in the plenary vote due this week. However, in addition to my vote in favour, I consider it important to emphasise some aspects of the Commission's proposal for an amendment. Above all, I consider it essential to monitor the proper use of extra payments thoroughly and closely. I would also like to draw attention to the fact that the proposal ignores a number of important principles such as co-financing, subsidiarity, additionality or equal treatment. These principles are decisive in cohesion policy, so I support the Commission's proposal for an amendment in view of the specific situation in Greece, but I think it is important that this be a one-off and individual measure and does not set a precedent or have an impact on the shaping of the future nature of cohesion policy.  I also consider it necessary to avoid the Commission presenting similar proposals for amendments in the future merely at the initiative of the Euro summit, as this will damage the participation of non-euro area Member States in the decision-making process. Last but not least, I consider it necessary to clarify the actual budgetary effects as soon as possible. It is important that the proposals in the Commission's draft do not involve amendments to the MFT and do not affect the cohesion resources of Greece or the other Member States.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. – The financial and economic crisis has affected all the Member States of the European Union, but Greece has intervened in a special way. The country faces a lack of liquidity and public funds available for public investment, which are needed to promote sustainable recovery. However, the lack of liquidity and public finances must not hinder investments under programmes supported by the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund, because if these investments were stopped, the country would run into existential problems. I therefore agree with the European Commission's proposals, which will provide additional pre-financing for cohesion policy operational programmes for 2014-2020 under the Investment for growth and jobs goal. It is very important that the amount of the additional initial advance payments is used effectively and gets to the beneficiaries from the ESF, cohesion fund and EMFF as quickly as possible so that they can make the planned investments and receive reimbursements as soon as payment applications are submitted. We must be aware of the urgency and seriousness of this support and contribute to the overall efforts to provide assistance to Greece.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Cohesion policy is Europe's main investment policy. As the Sixth Cohesion Report has shown, even in times of crisis, it has done its job well and helped state and local authorities mitigate the effects of the economic downturn. Cohesion policy is also, by definition, a solidarity policy. It is designed to help those areas that are doing less well than others. It is for these reasons that I support the proposal to amend the regulation with a view to granting specific measures to Greece. I believe that the proposed solutions will ensure that, in this unique situation in greece, cohesion policy can continue to play its investment and pro-growth role there. The new rules will allow Greeks to complete their projects and start new ones. At the same time, care must be taken to ensure that the proposed solutions do not have negative budgetary consequences for other countries. Therefore, this change must be of an exceptional and one-off nature.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: in writing. – I agree with the measures proposed in the report, which meet Greece's requirements. However, I believe that measures to increase the absorption of structural and investment funds from 2007 to 2013, such as increasing co-financing from European funds to 100% of eligible expenditure, should also be extended to some Member States with a lower absorption of European funds, such as Romania and Bulgaria. These Member States, like Greece, are in danger of losing billions of euros of European funds allocated in 2007-2013.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: PPE), in writing. – The green light for 100% funding for NSRF projects - exclusively for Greece - is a special opportunity for our country. These funds, accompanied by development measures, will substantially support the Greek economy and will be able to generate significant additional investments for years to come, paving the way for the rapid implementation of the Programme for Employment and Growth in Greece. This measure translates into direct additional liquidity of around EUR 500 million. EUR 2 billion and savings for the Greek budget of EUR 2 billion. Euro.  We must not forget that Greece is the only country in the EU still plagued by an economic downturn, while unemployment and especially youth unemployment are at unseen heights. This exemption for 100% funding will enable our country not only to make the most of the last euro from European funding, but also to contribute to increasing employment and relieving the weakest social strata affected by the crisis by the targeted channelling of these funds.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: The next item is the report by Eleni Theocharous, on behalf of the Committee on Development, on the role of local authorities in developing countries in development cooperation (2015/2004(INI)) (A8—0232/2015).

name: Eleni THEOCHAROUS
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would like to thank all those who have contributed to the writing and presentation, before the plenary, of this report and the shadow rapporteurs. The presentation is made in a very consensual way, I would say, and without too many controversial points. The report refers to the role of local authorities as development actors and underlines the importance of the factors that constitute an effective development policy. It also refers to the mechanisms by which the European Union can support local authorities in developing countries in implementing development programmes.  Strengthening the role of local authorities is important and depends on an improved economic and social environment for the implementation of Millennium Development Goals. These objectives are important for reducing poverty and improving the living of citizens in each region, but especially in urban centres and where there are, concentrated and in high density, populations living under miserable conditions, i.e. in slums, for example. The ultimate objective is to create conditions for the provision of effective Community services and development by local authorities.  The report builds on the post-2015 development programme and the Rio + 20 conclusions. The report therefore underlines the need for effective global cooperation both between the public and private sectors, as well as between states, local authorities as institutions of the various states and the social base. In the general axes of the report, it is stressed that development comes from the improvement of the mechanisms of action of local authorities and arises from the principles of local responsibility, democracy and capacity that local authorities must have in order to achieve predetermined objectives.  The importance of the participation of indigenous peoples is supported in order to achieve the objectives set. This means strengthening participatory democracy and increasing controls and therefore restrictions on corruption. If anyone listened to the previous debate, they would understand exactly what we are trying to say. It is clear the important role played by technology and the means it provides, as well as the importance of exploiting the natural resources of each region in order to achieve local development.  What should be given particular attention and emphasis should be placed on are relations between central authorities and local authorities, which vary according to the state systems of each country and, above all, the level of democracy. The quality and effectiveness of local authorities are relevant to the democratic power of the central authority and the political stability of the country. The powers and responsibilities of the Centre are important and essential when they provide an effective functioning, through local authorities and aim to combat poverty, social inequality with the ultimate aim of development. A major problem is the inability to cooperate with sound local authorities when the central authority is plagued by corruption.  At this point, I have also tried to put my personal experience of a 25-year-old action in Africa. In these circumstances, two important directions are relevant between relations between central authority and local authorities. Firstly, the granting, where necessary, of more powers and responsibilities to local authorities, particularly in large countries, for the purposes of decentralisation and effective administration. Secondly, the granting, from the centre to local authorities, of special powers. The first dimension is interlinked with the second and vice versa.  The European Union has an obligation to pursue a positive policy on the basis of mutual respect for developing countries, knowing that solving the problems in these countries also relieves us of many problems within the European Union, such as the continuous, uncontrolled and dangerous waves of migrants themselves.  Therefore, development in poor countries means, at the same time, fewer problems in the European Union itself and an increase in the conditions for cooperation for a better world, for the implementation of the human rights of every citizen, in all the lengths and widths of the earth. The proper allocation of development aid is based significantly on local authorities.

name: Neven Mimica
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, as this Assembly knows, policy is local and, as with any other policy, development cooperation policy also has to be local. That is why I would like to thank Parliament for its resolution on the role of local authorities in development cooperation. It highlights a common belief that the roots of democracy and well-being are local. Development starts at the local level. Most jobs, basic social services, political and civic rights are provided first and foremost in cities or regions or through local branches of government. Moreover, I agree with the resolution where it states that, in order to be adequate and legitimate, policies have to be defined through a bottom-up approach. This means that they have to start with local authorities.  I am convinced that the newly adopted 2030 agenda for sustainable development can only be of benefit if all actors are involved and mobilised. To that end, all public and private representatives, including local authorities, have to be involved in the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals. The world’s urban population will reach 70% by 2050. Having a specific goal dedicated to urbanisation is therefore of crucial importance. But beyond the specific Sustainable Development Goal, cities will be the frontline of all other issues, including migration, environmental sustainability, climate resilience, fragility and inequalities. Local authorities will need human, institutional and financial resources to fulfil their missions. The transfer of financial resources from central governments remains a difficult aspect of decentralisation, and it is often overlooked. All these issues are a question of sovereignty. We will address this through our political dialogue with partner countries, with the objective of ensuring coherent and efficient implementation. Since 2013, the Commission has been working on empowering local authorities in partner countries for enhanced governance and more effective development outcomes. This work will now be intensified. We have started to deliver on this commitment following four priorities, which are: supporting decentralisation reforms and local initiatives; strengthening the capacity of local authorities; addressing the challenges brought to the fore by rapid urbanisation; and engaging with associations of local authorities at all levels. These priorities are all covered by the resolution to be adopted in Parliament. As an example of our cooperation, in January this year the Commission signed the first framework partnership agreements with five global and regional associations of local authorities. These agreements formalise our reinforced support. We are also backing up our political commitment by providing adequate resources: EUR 450 million has already been secured from the dedicated programme of the Instrument for Development Cooperation on civil society organisations and local authorities. All EU instruments are gradually taking local governments into account as well. Approximately EUR 1.7 billion will be used to support decentralisation reforms, rural development and local governance in the period up to 2020. These precious resources must be used to ensure delivery and concrete results in empowering local authorities in the implementation of development cooperation.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: on behalf of the PPE Club. – Madam President, here ten days ago at the United Nations summit, heads of state and government adopted a new agenda for sustainable development. Then a consensus was reached on a global development strategy. A great deal of work has been done, but now there is that many more difficult, challenging part, i.e. fulfill promises or transform words into actions. The implementation of as many as 17 sustainable development goals is a major challenge and requires the formation of a global partnership that will include all participants. Therefore, that is why I would like to support the rapporteur and congratulate her on this report, which deals with important global development actors, i.e. local authorities.  In its report on the new global development framework adopted last November, the European Parliament highlighted local authorities as key players both in the creation and implementation of the new development agenda. Mep Theocharous's report reaffirms the view of members of this House that good governance is needed at all levels of government – local, national and international – in order to achieve development goals, eradicate poverty and ensure a dignified life for all people.  In a final document adopted in New York, Target 11 on sustainable development in urban areas was also adopted. It is quite clear that the implementation of this goal is possible only with close cooperation with local authorities. However, local government participation must not be limited to this objective. Local authorities are key to achieving all other goals, but also for collecting data, measuring results for transparency and accountability. In addition to the best understanding of the need for local authorities as the level of power closest to citizens, decentralisation of power is also an effective tool in the fight against corruption, construction and democracy and the protection of human rights, and this is what many developing countries need most.

name: Louis-Joseph MANSCOUR
text: On behalf of the Group of President and Women, ladies and gentlemen, just a few weeks before COP 21, to be held in Paris, and while the international community has just adopted the new Sustainable Development Goals, this report and this debate are timely.  First of all, I want to congratulate the rapporteur. This text gives us the opportunity to recall the crucial role played by local authorities in defining and implementing European and international development policy. As a provider of basic public services such as health, education, including water and sanitation, we are measuring how much the expertise of these authorities in these key areas will play a key part in the success of our commitment to eradicating poverty.  The eleventh sustainable development objective for cities allows local authorities to be fully recognised as central players in international cooperation. I think that we can modestly see this as a victory for the European Union and, above all, for our Parliament, which has been constantly stressing the key role of decentralisation and decentralised cooperation in improving the living conditions of the world's poorest.  The Commission must now take up this report and the proposals it contains to promote a development policy based on multi-level governance. As such, it is high time that decentralisation became a full-fledged financial concentration of the European Union for developing countries. I will conclude my remarks by echoing the words of Kofi Annan, former Secretary-General of the United Nations who, at the launch of the Millennium Development Goals in 2000, stressed that their achievement would be local or not. These words resonate with the same acuity at the dawn of the new goals that will be ours until 2030.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: on behalf of the ECR Club. – Madam President, I could agree in principle with the spirit of this Resolution, as I myself often point out that decisions crucial to the lives of citizens should be taken as closely as possible to them and their families. It is in the interest of citizens that local authorities have the necessary capacity to adopt a sustainable development strategy and make appropriate use of the available funding. However, I cannot help noticing that the approach proposed in this text is based on erroneous assumptions. Indeed, the public sector cannot play a major role in the launch and implementation of development plans, as this usually means increasing public spending and reduced efficiency and competitiveness with a greater tax burden on citizens and businesses. It is SMEs that need to take the lead and be growth-bearers in developing countries, while local government must pave the way for them by reducing taxes and administrative burdens.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. – Madam Vice-President, Mr. Commissioner of the European Commission, back in the 1990s when I was very engaged in the political life of Croatia, I preached and few listened to me. I must say that the role of local and regional authorities can be crucial for faster development of the state, for solving the problem of unemployment, for stronger social, economic or better environmental policies.  Likewise, the second experience I had when I was vice president of ARLEM, when we had cooperation with the southern Mediterranean coast in this organization that brings together regional and local authorities of the European Union and regional and local authorities of the southern part of the Mediterranean, was seen how important it is for them to have direct relations and direct cooperation with us. It is in this context that I am convinced that what Mr. Commissioner Mimica, who knows me well and who knows how much I have advocated the importance and role of regional and local authorities in Croatia, are precisely examples that he himself has presented in support of the fact that two principles, the principle of subsidy and the principle of decentralization, must be fully taken into account in cooperation with our partners in developing countries.  I propose that the European Commission really maximises the cooperation between our cities, our big cities and smaller cities, as well as rural environments in developing countries and how essential for strengthening democracy, for strengthening development, is precisely to encourage cooperation and exchange of experiences that large cities in Europe have that are needed by large cities in African countries, for example Cairo which really needs our help in its business planning for example. It does not always have to be financial, it can be given in many other ways, by overtaking the experiences that our cities, municipalities and rural areas have achieved in the European Union. And in this way we can help our partners in developing countries.  I think we have a good document and that on these foundations we can achieve a good policy of cooperation with developing countries.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, development cooperation cannot be the exclusive competence of national governments or international institutions. Local entities are the closest to people and must have autonomy to be protagonists in a process involved for their own development.  We often see how development cooperation is marked by supranational interests, with a strong character of trade and investment interests that often obviates the true needs of peoples. Local authorities can escape these dynamics in a way that serves as a tool for endogenous development in line with their true priorities. The participation of civil society, NGOs, producers, local trades, trade unions, associations is essential, thus promoting co-responsibility and setting aside the old paradigm of donors and beneficiaries that is so reminiscent of charity.  In the face of this old idea we are committed to the paradigm of partners and colleagues, that is, for solidarity between peoples. Decentralizing is democratizing; we need local governments to have the freedom and capacity to drive new agents of change in their territories, thus multiplying the actors that allow them to share and face the problems of each locality.  The United Nations' new sustainable development goals are yet another reason to promote local development from the local level, promoting direct and participatory cooperation, not paternalistic cooperation.

name: Maria HEUBUCH
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I very much welcome the report and I welcome the growing recognition at international level that local authorities in developing countries, as state actors, must play a central role in development cooperation. Because it is the local authorities that are closest to the population. They are the ones who know what the social, environmental, economic needs, problems, but also the challenges on the ground are. They also play an important role in the processes of democratisation and decentralisation and must be supported and promoted accordingly. So, they also need increased financial support. More resources are needed here. They must be more closely involved as full actors in the implementation of the 11th European Development Fund, both at partner and regional level, as well as in their sectoral and budget support. Commissioner, we need a genuine political dialogue with local authorities within the framework of European cooperation. We need to start this in order to identify ongoing progress and difficulties and to provide prospects for more efficient aid at local level.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are all in a state of Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Mimica, we assume that Mrs Theocharous's report is a job well done because it is a work that comes out of a committee that cares about the issues of development and international cooperation.  Unfortunately, however, we have to note on the other hand that what we manage to get out of Parliament, or what is proposed as a committee, does not receive feedback from the States, from those who would still have the best chance of supporting, financing and changing their development and international cooperation policies. Because it is clear that if you go to the international summits, if you go to the forums and talk about a change of programme, about the fact that the objectives are being combined, these 17 objectives that we have talked about, but then we continue to support aggressive policies on the part of European multinationals in these same developing countries, it becomes very difficult to implement what we are proposing.  We also have a great many cases of state participation by European states exploiting resources before the territories we are talking about, we are talking about oil, we are talking about water, we are talking about energy in general and from those countries the voices that are heard are voices of the kind but let us use our resources in peace. On the other hand, we have often and willingly given money that has largely been lost on the street due to the very high rate of corruption.  So the question we have to ask is: how can we succeed in improving, that is, how can we actually ensure that this money is not lost and that development becomes effective? I believe that we should change our strategy, perhaps link multiannual funding to objectives, to levels to be achieved and then, step by step, refinance if certain standards are achieved. It's a very complicated job. I am pleased that there is the right approach from this Parliament and that the Commission is cooperative. We must be able to put more pressure on the Member States.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Ladies and gentlemen, I thank our colleague for this contribution, but I must confess that I am not convinced. This report is first and foremost a translation of the failure of previous policies aimed at African states and in particular States.  Over the past sixty years, more than $1 trillion has been spent on development assistance. Nearly half of Africans still live on one euro a day. In the last half-century, wars and massacres have killed ten million people, eighty coups. Eleven countries have experienced civil wars in 15 years, which have cost, beyond human lives, nearly two hundred billion dollars, not to mention the corruption that is estimated by the African Union at one hundred and fifty billion dollars a year.  How, then, can we talk about development aid? A nascent economy requires stable institutions, functioning public services and opportunities for young people.  Addressing, as we do, lower communities will not solve anything. To combat corruption, control migration flows and promote development, three priorities are needed: to condition aid in a project logic and no longer in a window logic, to ensure transparency and control to eradicate corruption networks and to punish the actions of multinationals predatory raw materials or juicy markets without regard for local populations. Finally, trust the new generations who wish to get by themselves and who are struggling to emancipate themselves from local administrative or cultural rigidities. Helping to help will be of no use if we continue to support structurally corrupt powers.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I thank Eleni Theocharous for her work on the report, which stresses the importance of local authorities for development. Local authorities are closest to their communities. Like no one else knows their needs. We also see this in our regions in the Member States of the European Union. Building this awareness in developing countries is crucial not only for central and local authorities, but also for citizens. The centres of government should support the decentralisation process and communicate good governance patterns, competences and funding so that they are used most efficiently at local level. Local authorities, in turn, must be open both to dialogue with residents and to cooperation with civil society organisations, other administrations and private partners. These partnerships have a real impact on increasing social inclusion by promoting education, strengthening micro, small and medium-sized enterprises, creating jobs and promoting sustainable economic growth in the region. I would also like to emphasise the key role of local authorities in crisis situations. Fair distribution of humanitarian aid, which must first reach the most vulnerable groups, cannot be impossible without good governance and dialogue with partners and aid organisations. Taking all these arguments into account, it is desirable that local authorities should be better represented in the international negotiations for the adoption of the post-2015 development agenda.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, all too often we have seen the failure of cooperation policies which, between waste, corruption and inefficiency, have unfortunately failed to achieve their objectives and to provide real added value for the citizens and populations to whom they were addressed.  The data tell us that in developing countries, population growth is concentrated in urban areas. From here, therefore, it is clear that the key to ensuring that the efforts and projects put in place really improve the living conditions of the people is the involvement of the indigenous institutions, that is, within the countries themselves. Local authorities must be made accountable and adequate levels of transparency must be ensured in the management of resources and in the allocation of funds through, above all and above all, real participation by associations and civil society, with which a recovery path must be shared. Education, health, housing and decent living conditions cannot allow for waste or delay.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to support the contents of this report on the role of local institutions in cooperation and development aid policy.  The key to success is the proximity to program management and the strength of the link that unifies those who help and those who receive help. Practice shows that, especially in rural areas, it is local institutions that best meet these requirements. At the local level, corruption risks are reduced and monitoring and evaluation improved. Locally, there is the key to sustainable territorial development and the promotion of more democratic governance. That is why the United Nations promotes and recognizes the local role in cooperation policies. Therefore, the local must be adequately recognised and integrated into the functioning of the eleventh European Development Fund (EDF). The success of these cooperation policies is one of the keys to promoting sustainable development in the most depressed areas of the planet. It is also a key to European immigration policy. It is, in short, the natural expression of the necessary coexistence between measures requiring a comprehensive approach, such as visa policy or the common security and defence policy, and this area of cooperation in which the local and regional take precedence. The report also concerns another particularly important issue also for the construction of a Europe that is indeed the sum of all its diversity. This is the financial adequacy of local and regional entities. This is another essential condition for harmonious development also in Europe and one of the keys to maintaining financial effort in terms of cooperation. The Basque Country, thanks to its commitment to these policies and a well-structured financing system, remains at the head of the Spanish State in this area. A report by Intermon Oxfam highlights that it is the region that spends the most effort in this field with 18 euros per inhabitant per year. We have to follow suit.

name: Jordi Vicent SEBASTIA TALAVERA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, before I arrived here, the European Parliament, I was mayor of my people — Burjassot - a wonderful European people, and I can assure you that the topic which says that local administrations are the closest to the citizen is absolutely true. They are the ones that citizens address first when they have needs, when they want services, when they have problems, and on many occasions these same local entities have to deal with that without being properly funded. In developing countries, their role as direct partners in cooperation policy is final. They are key policy actors, not only for economic development, but also for improving democracy in communities and ensuring decentralized, effective, participatory and transparent action of our cooperation; that cooperation that is sometimes lost in these often corruption-tinged macrostructures are also dynamic actors, not mere recipients, who know the real needs of their citizens, and not those approaches that we sometimes send from here designed in offices far removed from what those people really want and need, which we, in theory, want to help. That is why we support the report and call for clear recognition of this role, also with direct budgetary support implemented in the eleventh European Development Fund.  (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: David COBURN
text: blue-card question. – Would you not agree with me that interfering in the good ordering of national governments, through the EU giving money to local governments, is surely an EU plot to destroy the sovereign nation-state by stealth and by buying local politicians? Do you agree with me, sir?

name: Jordi Vicent SEBASTIA TALAVERA
text: "blue card" response. – Well, no, I do not share at all this theory of European conjuring in order to destroy the sovereignty of national states, not even the European states, which you very often cite. It seems to me quite the opposite: that this report wants to bet on the real effectiveness of this development aid in places where it is really much needed and that it also takes into account, in particular, local reality, because that is where the problems are being suffered. Therefore, I believe that your question has nothing to do with what I have stated.

name: Nathan GILL
text: – Madam President, it is a fact that corruption in developing nations is endemic. This has been the case for decades, and it has become an almost cultural norm in many countries that find it difficult to make national and local government transparent and accountable. The idea that somehow bypassing the top layer of government will see less waste of our money is a naive idea, to say the least. The Turkish proverb ‘the fish stinks from the head down’ is very pertinent here. If you have a corrupt national government it is safe to say that there will be corruption within a nation at every level. The idea that it will be easier to police hundreds or even thousands of local authorities when you cannot do the job with dozens of national governments is ludicrous. One of the first duties of government is to ensure that the taxes that they collect from their citizens are treated with respect. If we cannot guarantee that the aid we hand over is managed within a framework in which we have confidence, if we cannot be sure that we are not propping up corrupt regimes or paying for fleets of Mercedes limos and private jets, then we should not be handing over aid at all. The message should be: get your own house in order if you expect our help. Paying local authorities directly undermines the nation state and could be used to gerrymander the overthrow of legitimate, but poor, governments pursuing EU objectives. If the EU directly funds tribal councils in Africa or the Middle East it will undermine national unity in the strength of legitimate central authorities. Surely, rewarding good governance and refusing to reward bad governance should be the ethos of development aid.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as promoter of the first decentralised cooperation programmes in France, having founded the Regional Institute for Cooperation and Development in the Alsace region, that of Champagne-Ardenne, member and secretary general of the first national commission for decentralised cooperation, having also promoted in Europe with the support of the European Union, the first programmes of decentralised cooperation, I could only support your report. I must note, however, that the European institutions, once again, have this permanent ability to divert good ideas into tools of European ideology. Real decentralised cooperation is taking place - I apologize for flaunting my experience - in the following way.  We must not go over the states - we must always intervene with their agreement. In this report, decentralized entities are treated as quasi-state actors! It is necessary to support existing decentralized partnerships and to support dynamics, to promote them, at most through calls for North-South cooperation projects.  We must not create proactive artificial dynamics; you should always have a partner in the north and a partner in the south and ask for supervised responsibility from the local partner in the north, in the management of aid to the south. Just because the partner is local does not mean that they are not subject to embezzlement.  Finally, we need to deepen this virtuous logic of short circuits - decentralisation is only one way, not an end - to ensure that decentralized cooperation is made from civil society to civil society, from hospital to hospital, from chamber of trades and agriculture to chamber of trades and agriculture, with the North and the South. Then we will be effective and useful for development. Thirty years have been lost.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: – Madam President, I would first of all like to congratulate my colleague Eleni Theocharous on drafting this report. Today's debate is, I think, important, because it takes place shortly after the adoption in New York of the 2030 Agenda on Sustainable Development. As is well known, it is an ambitious agenda, which also includes the desire to end extreme poverty and to engage all countries on the path of sustainable development by 2030. At the level of implementation, the involvement of local authorities and civil society will be crucial if, of course, the Sustainable Development Goals become a reality. As the Theocharous report points out, local authorities have a major role to play in ensuring the link between citizens and government, as well as in building democratic ownership of the development agenda at the level of each country. That is why it is essential to support the action of local authorities, in order to enable them to fully assume this role in the provision of basic services, but also to ensure participation and accountability at sub-national level, despite what Mr Schaffhauser said earlier, which does not see this level at all. I also think it is important to support the institutional capacity building of local authorities and, as the Theocharous report says, there is a need for a political dialogue between local authorities within the framework of our development cooperation. Finally, as a permanent rapporteur on the coherence of development policies, I want to stress that local authorities can also play an important role in this regard, because they can promote and monitor this concept. However, their role in development policies, development policy coherence, has not been sufficiently explored at European level or outside the Union. We therefore need, I believe, a specific framework for the policy of coherence for development to be carried out within an inclusive framework. Thank you for your attention. (The speaker agreed to answer a question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: David COBURN
text: blue-card question. – Surely this is extending the tentacles of corruption of the European Union throughout the world? This is wrong. Nation-states should be respected and the order of government should be respected. This is appalling. I hope you will agree with me.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I was in a meeting last week where I heard it said that individual MEPs could ask only one blue-card question during a debate. Is Mr Coburn able to get the floor as often as he wants to ask blue-card questions after every speaker and disrupt the debate?

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: answer to a question asked in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Madam President, to be honest, I do not understand the link - intellectually speaking - between respect for the nation-state and what the honourable Member has said, namely development understood only as a purchase by the authorities. There is no logical connection between these two universes, between the universe of the nation-state and this absurd correlation. Development does not mean buying territories or authorities. It's, I think, a mistake of understanding. Perhaps the Member did not get the debate right. Maybe he wanted to go to another gym. Thanks.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, local authorities will play an essential role in achieving the post-2015 Sustainable Development Goals that have just been adopted in New York and that shape the new global development agenda for the next 15 years. Moreover, they play a crucial role in safeguarding vulnerable populations in fragile crisis conditions. I strongly support partnership programmes with local authorities with a view to ensuring that they are the main actors who implement the new agenda at the level that is closest to citizens. Acknowledgement of their role as state stakeholders represents a major step forward for the European Union’s new development agenda.  However, these new guidelines must be translated into effective implementation, both in terms of the 11th European Development Fund and in terms of the development cooperation instrument. Promoting decentralised cooperation is a way of implementing the post-2015 development framework and should become a priority funding sector for our external aid financing instruments.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: – Madam President, a locally driven approach and greater civic participation are the keys to achieving more effective poverty reduction and equitable development. In implementing the post-2015 development agenda, the fact that the local dimension is of utmost importance must be further acknowledged. The engagement of local authorities in dialogue must be considered essential. In the resource-allocation process they reflect the closest possible connection between development aid and its intended beneficiaries. They are the first to respond to the changing needs of local society, and they provide basic services in terms of access to education, health and sanitation. By reinforcing decentralised public aid and fostering partnership with the private sector, we can improve social cohesion and inclusive economic growth. Nevertheless, cooperation with local authorities must be monitored and controlled by good governance so that the results are lasting and do not dissolve when incentives are withdrawn.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: – The European Union must continue to be actively involved in supporting local authorities and promoting democratic and transparent governance. Local authorities will be crucial in achieving the objectives set for the post-2015 period, as they represent a strong link between the European Union's objectives, national objectives and global objectives. It is very important that, in future, we are able to better involve civil society organisations, local authorities and national parliaments, thereby empowering local authorities, thereby ensuring proper transparent and accountable governance through this process. I also consider it equally important that we strive to create more new and decent jobs. The European Union and its Member States, as the largest donors of official development assistance, but also key policy makers and decentralised cooperation actors, should remain the driving force during the next phase of negotiations within the UN. I believe that, in future, aid for developing countries must be better targeted in order to respond to the needs of the most vulnerable sections of the population. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Nathan GILL
text: blue-card question. – Whenever money is given, there is always some kind of underlying politics. I just wonder how you would feel if Russia decided that the local authorities in your country were in need of some development aid and started paying your councils money. Would you like that? Would you think that would be acceptable to the people in your area?

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Mr President, this was a very bad question just towards my country. My country has received tremendous help before it joins the European Union itself, and I am very glad that the European Union is precisely the force and the very actor that helps such countries.

name: Ramona Nicole MĂNESCU
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, first of all I would like to congratulate my colleague Eleni Theocharous on this important report. I think it is very important to be able to support national governments, but also local authorities in developing countries, both through financial means and by providing technical assistance to them. It is necessary and urgent for the European Union to make effective use of its external and development policies to combat poverty, but also to the causes that generate and sustain conflict. Lack of education and prospects for young people, poverty, unemployment, discrimination, marginalisation and corruption make young generations the safe victims of radicalisation and extremism, as we have seen, and condemn citizens to poverty and insecurity. Preventing and resolving these conflicts and developing must be priorities within a coordinated global strategy of the European Union, which uses both diplomatic and security tools and economic and human rights resolution tools.  A good example is the financial support that the European Union has promised and must give to the authorities of Jordan, Lebanon and Turkey. It is extremely important to help these states, which have made an impressive humanitarian effort and not only in the management of refugee camps, but also in supporting local authorities, which have difficulty providing health, education and social assistance services for their own citizens. At the same time, however, I believe it is vital to have effective international cooperation in order to monitor whether these funds are really being used for the purposes for which they were intended. Thank.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to make a very realistic speech, starting from the observation of many mistakes, failures and missed goals of European cooperation. Let us be honest, if all the huge European resources that have been used in recent decades had been used in effective development projects, really capable of changing local realities and with the participation of the people and without corruption and waste, we would have another Africa today, we would have another Middle East and we would have prevented a great deal of conflict and so much poverty.  We must therefore give a new impetus, a stimulus consistent with the things we say, which is aimed precisely at enhancing the role of local authorities, both in donor and recipient countries, in short, mobilising the capacities of non-state actors, of the resources that there are, including those of civil society. I would say enough is enough, let us limit the major projects which, even at European level, require such a wide threshold for participation that it cuts out a great many experiences of NGOs working on the ground, no more multinational cooperation megagalactics and large, expensive and bureaucratic international organisations.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: – I am pleased to agree on the important role local authorities can play as development actors. We also agreed on ambitious development goals. However, the local level can only play its role under certain conditions. In order to achieve the objectives, it is important that the local authority be democratically constituted, organised and funded in such a way that it can competently and successfully carry out development tasks at its level. In this context, I welcome the rapporteur's emphasis on decentralisation. This makes sense if the principle of subsidiarity is applied, which has harmonised different levels of decision-making in Europe and has contributed to greater efficiency in achieving development goals. I see another important emphasis in the principle of participability. Effective implementation of development policies must be achieved through dialogue and cooperation between public authorities, the private sector, science, civil society and citizens. As a third important element and a challenge, I would like to mention the principle of good governance, which is not without accountability, transparency and respect for the rule of law. In this way, we would most effectively approach the 16th post-16 objective, which is about working for peaceful and inclusive societies. Only such societies can trajectory into sustainable development.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, decision-making should always take place as close to citizens as possible. That is a key aspect of democracy and a core value of the EU. It is clear, therefore, that local authorities have a crucial role to play in sustainable development, centred on citizen participation and grassroots engagement. Development cooperation also depends on intercultural understanding and dialogue. This is something which the Millennium Development Goals underestimated and which will, hopefully, be rectified in future. Local authorities can play an important role in dialogue with their counterparts in Europe. There are common issues to address, and best practice on both sides – such as the exemplary Brazilian participatory budgeting model – should be considered. One issue that is hardly mentioned in the report is gender equality, including women’s representation. Improving gender balance in local government is a crucial aspect of women’s empowerment and will make for more holistic, inclusive and sustainable development. However, this is not just a development issue. In England, for example, only 32% of local councillors are women. To conclude, we need to strive towards this goal together.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the European Union has set ambitious objectives in development cooperation for the coming years, a work for which we need everyone's participation in order to be able to move forward as much as we have set out. As we are seeing here this afternoon, the role of local entities in the countries to which our aid is addressed is critical, but here in Europe too we must know how to channel and mobilize all our resources and strengths to draw on the experience, resources and, in many cases, the advantages that closeness offers. Because of its proximity to the African continent and the decades-long ties with local and national authorities in West African countries, the Canary Islands can play a significant role in helping to achieve European development aid objectives. In fact, it already does so today, as in Gran Canaria there is a logistics base of the United Nations World Food Programme and the port of Las Palmas also hosts the humanitarian aid logistics centre of the International Red Cross. Since 2013, the United States Agency for Regional Development has also had two ships in this port for the development of its humanitarian work in Africa. The Canary Islands is in a strategic place — no one doubts it – and has contacts with many African countries, to which 30% of European development aid is earmarked, which may be very appropriate to advance the objective we are discussing here this afternoon to achieve greater collaboration between the local authorities of the Member States of the European Union and those of developing countries , so that we can all draw much more positive consequences.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: – Madam President, in many Member States of the European Union local and regional authorities are officially competent to participate in national development policies through decentralised cooperation. They can therefore be seen as direct players in the Union's development policy and foreign affairs. I believe that municipalities and regions need to have greater involvement, based on partnership and expertise, by focusing efforts primarily on specific areas that fall within the competence of local or regional public administration. Sustainable development can only be ensured if certain responsibilities lie with those who are best aware of the specific realities and characteristics at local and regional level.  However, we must not forget the essential role of local authorities, namely as guarantor of social and territorial cohesion.  Thanks.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to first congratulate Eleni Theocharous on this excellent report, for which her experience on the ground gives her legitimacy to make the recommendations. I would like to focus on 3 elements.  First, it is clear that the role of local authorities is becoming unavoidable if development aid is to be more effective. The definition, in conjunction with local authorities, of a limited number of priorities should enable a better fit and ownership of the projects implemented. It is also a way of sharing responsibility with state actors who are as close as possible to the citizens. Secondly, I believe that it is time to make local authorities cooperate more closely for development because it is through them that we can promote the emergence of democracy, prevent and cure conflicts, which, as we know, are one of the main obstacles to development in many countries. Recognition of the role of local authorities must also improve women's participation in decision-making, as a matter of principle and because it is known that the positive development benefits are significant.  Finally, the commission's new communication guidelines on local authorities must be translated into concrete action today in the implementation of the 11th EDF. There is no more time to waste EU aid paying off: let us not turn a blind eye to the links between today's migration crisis and the perfectibility of our European development policy.  Finally, I hope that this report will be forwarded, beyond the Council and the Commission, to the local authorities of our Member States, to the African Union for example, to our ACP partners, to highlight precisely the role of local authorities in development cooperation.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her My group also supports this report. I believe that it is a good and balanced report which adequately identifies the difficulties of development policy and the fight against poverty and proposes the right solutions. The principle of subsidiarity is indeed being applied here, and strengthening local authorities is the right way to proceed. Other instruments, such as the use of micro-credits or private sector participation and the raising of financial resources from the private sector, are also important elements of a successful development policy. However, I would also like to point out that what has been worked out so well here should also be applied in very different contexts. Because we have just had a debate on how we are getting the special aid to Greece off the market. And this special aid – where we have now suddenly made EUR 35 billion available from medium-term financial planning, which was supposed to last several years – is precisely not respecting the principle of subsidiarity. This is where major projects are suddenly being funded. Suddenly, it is dispensed with the fact that self-financing shares and co-financing shares are included. There is a real attempt here with the watering can from above to promote economic development, which would also be much better suited to the local authorities.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I also want to thank the rapporteur for the report presented. In my opinion, the role of local authorities, subsidiarity and decentralisation are not really an empty concept, and I am therefore glad that the petitioner also appreciates and appreciates local authorities in this regard.  It has been said in the debate that the fish smells from the head and it is a question of what is really the role of local authorities in the development of the European area. I do not think that this statement can in any way be accepted and I can illustrate this on concrete examples. In the Czech Republic, the level of public debt is EUR 70 billion. Local authorities account for only three billion in public debt, that is, municipalities and regions, that is, one-twentieth of that amount. Therefore, the question is to what extent municipalities, municipalities, regions should also be held accountable for the government's performance, that is, how local authorities can be penalised if the government does not comply with budgetary policy. That, too, should be considered.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, local authorities really can play an important role in development and, above all, in poverty reduction. At the same time, we will also have a strengthening of economic democracy, because this strengthens decentralisation, proximity, subsidiarity and participation. This is of particular value in a world that is moving forward with a multi-level governance, with the participation of the citizens themselves.  However, in order to provide resources for local government, the budgets of developing countries must not go towards debt servicing. That is why the most important thing is to write off the debt of developing countries. The second is to use Regulation 472/2013 to audit the debt in the countries of the European Union, in particular Greece, and to write off the shameful debt. Finally, let me say to my colleague, Mr Lucke, about the EUR 35 billion that of these, EUR 15 billion for Greece is to support farmers with subsidies and the rest is given on the condition that, my dear colleague, Germany will also get... (The President interrupts the speaker).

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: – Madam Rapporteur, I would like to thank you very much for a very inspiring report. Local authorities play a key role in protecting vulnerable populations in fragile states affected by the crisis and their role should in no way be underestimated. Especially today, when the European Union is facing the consequences of a major humanitarian crisis that has affected some countries in the Middle East and North Africa. A peaceful state, economic prosperity and the cohesion of communities and local authorities are the keys to resolving the current crisis. We must not forget that many refugees in the European Union do not want to live and are fleeing their homes because of civil wars and the poor economic situation in their countries. I was happy to read that the report calls for the creation of local consultation platforms in the context of budgetary planning, but I do not understand why it has not gone a small step further for women and spoken out in support of the introduction of participatory budgets. While I appreciate the emphasis on the role of civil society in local communities in the report, I cannot agree with the emphasis placed on the private sector.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – The global population will clearly rise to around nine billion, according to the dynamics shown in the statistics by 2050. And most of the growth is expected precisely in developing countries. And that is why the role of local authorities in these countries is all the more important.
