These are already facing the challenge of providing more and more residents with access to education, health care, food, housing and energy sources, so the need for additional financial resources will increase in the coming years. And the unique role of improving the situation in developing countries certainly has development aid, which in itself is not sufficient, so innovative sources of funding, such as blending mechanisms, must be used. Above all, I would like to draw attention to one more thing, and that is that even when used, they cannot remain unattended. And that is also the role of the European Parliament.

name: James CARVER
text: – Madam President, many developing states already feel that they have little control over the activities of both donors and NGOs. A good example of how a state tries to manage control of its situation is in Somaliland, where the Government has set up a national planning office, ensuring that there is a national strategy – that there is joined-up thinking and that funding is directed towards agreed national priorities. Like the UK Government and other actors, the EU, as a donor, has some input into these national priorities. Thus it is both absurd and contradictory to now discuss negotiating directly with local authorities, undermining national governments and accountability – very much in the model of the role that the EU readily takes with its own Member States.  This debate underlines your desire to assume the role of a neo-colonial power and highlights your lust for influence, thus showing a lack of consideration of how this strategy has a real chance of destroying young and fragile democracies. Shame on you all!

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, go raibh maith agat as ucht an seans a thabhairt dom cúpla focal a rá ar an ábhar tábhachtach seo mar a bhfuilimid ag tabhairt aitheantas don pháirt atá glactha ag údaráis áitiúla, ní hamháin inár dtíortha féin ach go háirithe sna tíortha atá ag forbairt.  Now it was a great Irish-American politician, Tip O’Neill, who said ‘all politics is local’. Certainly that is true, and I suppose local authorities are a prime example of that because they are closest to the people. For that reason it is important that we should work as closely as possible with them. Particularly now, in the global sense, we are looking for sustainable development goals. In Paris, where I will be representing Parliament, we will be hoping to get a global agreement on climate change. That is going to pose a huge challenge worldwide – and nowhere more so than in Africa where the population is bound to explode over the next number of years. Combining those targets with feeding a growing population is going to be a challenge, but, by working with local authorities, we may have a better chance than through governments.

name: Neven Mimica
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like once again to welcome and congratulate the rapporteur, Ms Theocharous, for this comprehensive and well-targeted report. We share a common vision: the idea that one of the key challenges for the next 15 years will be the localisation of the Sustainable Development Goals. This must not be just another repackaging of the usual existing actions. We need to think from the outset about data desegregation at sub-national level. This approach has to be a real new paradigm where local authorities in the north and the global south become strongly involved, not just in the implementation but also in the nurturing of the Sustainable Development Goals. This report is very welcome and it strengthens the EU’s views. We will continue to intensify, with your backing, our support to local authorities in development policy.

name: Eleni THEOCHAROUS
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I thank the Commissioner, all colleagues for their contribution to the debate. I want to talk to you about a myth of my country, from Greek mythology: about the myth of the Danes, where the Danes had the curse of trying to fill a pit that had a thousand holes, with water. This is now the countries that receive development aid, a point that has a thousand holes and what we are doing is trying to close some holes by strengthening local government. We are not trying to solve the whole problem by raising the issue of local government. I would like to say to my fellow Members a few things to look out for: development aid is one thing and charity is another. Today we are not asking for an increase in development aid, but for an increase in its effectiveness. In other words, the point is, this aid that we give to make way, to create infrastructure, so that people can live better.  Because if the methods we have used to date were effective, our report would not even be needed, the report would not make sense. And we are not talking, of course, about local self-government in Europe, but we are talking about local government in some other countries, where if some colleagues knew what is happening in poor countries, they would talk more fearfully about what might happen in the world and some people would not insist that the European Union cannot export democracy. Commissioner, much of what you have said, rather everything you have said, overlaps with what is included in the report. I would point out that generalisations and rules cannot apply to all states, all mentalities and all regions of the earth. There are democratically elected local authorities, but there are also areas where local government is in the hands of the tribal leader. All these things must be taken into account, taking into account the level of democracy from then on. If we respect all this, surely the result will be positive and we will not be talking about European-style local government.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, October 6, 2015. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. Strategic planning that integrates national and local level is essential to promote and integrate the three main dimensions of development: social, economic and environmental. The involvement of local authorities is therefore central, as they know the realities and their strengths and weaknesses. The new development agenda allows for such involvement and the report calls, in relation to specific areas, in particular the introduction of partnership agreements between local authorities in EU Member States and local authorities in developing countries. Training and human resources are among the sectors most concerned, with a view to promoting development which is not only linked to external intervention but aims to make communities autonomous.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. – The local authorities can and should play an important role in developing countries. Engaging them in development cooperation could lead to a better exchange of experiences and know-how that could strengthen the administrative capacity of local authorities from developing countries. Therefore the EU should try, through its development cooperation instruments, to integrate the rising involvement of local authorities from the different Member States in establishing better cooperation with partners from developing countries. This strategy of involving local authorities is linked to the Sustainable Development Goals that imply a stronger participation at local level and a direct partnership with the beneficiaries of development aid. Cooperation is needed at local level to assess better the needs of the population and the know-how brought by local authorities could lead to a better use of the development funds and projects already established by the European Union and the Member States.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The European Union is committed to supporting local authorities in developing countries, as this leads to poverty reduction and democratisation of local governance. Let the importance of these actions be demonstrated by the fact that the world's population is projected to grow from around 7 billion to 9.5 billion people by 2050. The main part of this increase will be for developing countries, in particular their urban areas.  However, while agreeing with the EU's support for local communities, I want to signal an important problem. European Union assistance cannot be unconditional aid. Among the various conditions set by the EU, the fight against corruption must also be required. Countries that do not make progress in the fight against corruption should not receive EU financial support. EU funds should be used to improve health systems, accessibility to education or transport. There is no excuse for EU funds being appropriated by local leaders.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on the oral issue at the Commission on legislation on mortgages and financial instruments at risk in the European Union: the case of Spain, by Cecilia Wikstrom, on behalf of the Committee on Petitions (O-000088/2015 - B8-0755/2015) (2015/2740 (RSP)).

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: author. – Madam President, the origin of this resolution and this debate that we are having tonight is numerous petitions that the Committee on Petitions has received during the past few years. As Chair of this Committee I fully understand, and regret to hear of, the difficulties faced by petitioners. Most petitions concern the situation in Spain but the same problems are also known in other Member States.  The Committee on Petitions is the bridge between EU citizens and EU institutions and, as its Chair, I strive for the EU to better take advantage of citizens’ direct experiences of EU law and also the experiences of national implementation, because these experiences can help us as legislators to further improve future legislation. In this role of bringing the concerns of citizens forward to this House, we have initiated this debate tonight. As I said, we have received a large number of petitions denouncing the violation of fundamental rights and infringement of EU legislation in connection with the lack of accurate consumer information related to practices in mortgage banking. Obtaining accurate information is crucial for making sound economic decisions, and of course vital when we talk about important personal investments for an individual citizen and his or her family.  These petitions highlight a number of abusive clauses and practices in the Spanish mortgage sector which have been identified by both national and European courts. A large number of citizens became victims of financial fraud as their savings banks sold them very risky financial instruments and they were not duly informed about the extent of the risks involved in the proposed investment; nor did the banks perform suitably tests to determine whether clients had the knowledge to understand the risk that they were undertaking. This has led to cases of terrible personal suffering and huge economic losses, where citizens have lost their home and all their life savings. Many tragedies have taken place before our eyes. However, I would like to stress that the aim of this question and the discussion tonight should be seen in a wider perspective. Our aim is to raise awareness and seek clarity regarding a general problem of bad banking practices that can be found all over Europe, not only within Spain. I would therefore like to stress that transparency and informed consumer protection will be essential components if we want to combat abusive terms in mortgage contracts and thus strengthen protection for borrowers. Nevertheless, on behalf of my committee, I would like to ask the Commission some questions related to this situation. I hope that the Commission’s investigation and conclusions will allow us to improve the situation for the petitioners and also to ensure that we can avoid this kind of practice in the future and consequently improve the application of European Union law. So, Commissioner, on the basis of the petitions, a number of questions should have an answer tonight. Do the petitions relate to the breach of banks’ obligations in relation to the information to be provided to clients under the Markets in Financial Instruments Directive (MiFID) I, as transposed by Spanish law? Has Spain properly transposed MiFID I or have Spanish national authorities properly enforced the applicable provisions? We are also asking what measures the Commission has taken or will take to address the abuses committed by companies selling financial instruments that affect small depositors and small owners of financial instruments such as preferred shares, which in many cases have been marketed without full compliance with EU legislation.  I would like to know, too, if the Commission is willing to take measures with regard to unfair clauses in Spanish mortgage law, in particular with regard to unfair commercial practices and the incorrect behaviour of the banks that provided all these people with the loans in question. I am looking forward to your answers, Commissioner Jourová, and also to hearing the views of my colleagues. And let me say, on a personal note, that we should be full of compassion for the people who have suffered terribly, but we should also make sure that future legislation is safe and sound for everyone in Europe.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, let me first reply to questions number one and number two. Yes, many Spanish consumers, especially borrowers, have recently found themselves in a very difficult economic situation. Problems in the mortgage market triggered many legal disputes in Spain, where the fairness of contracts was challenged. The Unfair Contract Terms Directive is a powerful tool in the hands of national judges and, in many cases, Spanish judges stepped in and declared contract terms, especially in mortgage contracts, unfair and non-binding on consumers. Related cases referred to the Court of Justice were widely discussed and drew a lot of media attention. The Court ruled that Spanish law as it stood at the time failed to provide certain procedural safeguards to consumers. As a consequence, the Spanish law has been amended on two occasions, giving the consumer an opportunity to object to mortgage enforcement and to appeal if such an objection is dismissed. The amendments also obliged the court to verify contracts on its own motion. Transitional provisions of Law 1/2013 are currently being challenged before the Court of Justice. In parallel, the Commission has conducted a wider assessment of the Spanish legislation and is currently in a structured dialogue with the Spanish authorities. I started this dialogue to ensure that all of the rulings of the Court of Justice are fully implemented in Spain.  Let me underline that I welcome the changes already introduced in Spain, as they improve the protection of consumers. Nevertheless, it still needs to be determined whether the Spanish rules on civil procedure, including on mortgage enforcement proceedings, are fully in conformity with the Unfair Contract Terms Directive. The replies of the Spanish authorities received last June by the Commission are being analysed and further action will be considered if the answers prove to be unsatisfactory.  Finally, as regards the sale of certain financial instruments by banks to retail clients, as stipulated by the Memorandum of Understanding on financial sector policy conditions of July 2012 between the Commission and Spain, Spain has amended its legislation by setting a significantly high minimum amount of investment in complex financial instruments, thereby de facto barring retail clients from buying such products. On question number three: as far as arbitration mechanisms are concerned, in the context of the financial assistance programme for Spain, the Spanish Fund for Orderly Bank Restructuring encourages the banks under its full control to set up arbitration mechanisms to address mis-selling, in particular of preferential shares by these banks to retail clients in 2012.  Based on data provided by the Spanish authorities, it appears that between 2012 and early 2015 these arbitration mechanisms issued around 298 000 rulings in favour of the applicants, thus upholding around 71% of all applications. In conjunction with the fact that the Spanish Deposit Guarantee Fund bought back from retail clients substantial amounts of such preferential shares, which had been sold in a misleading manner, this issue seems to have been remedied in the meantime.  As for your question number four, with regard to new legislation in the area of financial services, let me mention some important pieces of EU law recently adopted by the co-legislators, namely the Mortgage Credit Directive and the Markets in Financial Instruments Directive and Regulation. Creditors are responsible for informing consumers about the risks they undertake when getting involved in investments. They have a duty to be reasonably patient vis-à-vis their debtors before starting execution proceedings. This issue has been addressed in the Mortgage Credit Directive. Member States are required to adopt measures to encourage creditors to exercise reasonable forbearance before foreclosure proceedings are initiated. The European Banking Authority’s guidelines on arrears and foreclosure adopted on 1 June 2015 provide greater detail on how effect should be given to that provision. As to whether further measures should be taken at EU level to enable debt settlement procedures: to date debt settlement procedures are dealt with at national level but some jurisdictions already provide a possibility for borrowers who cannot repay their mortgage loans to be released in full from the underlying debt by handing their mortgaged property over to the lender. This is precisely the case in Spain under certain conditions. The Mortgage Credit Directive does not prevent such a procedure from remaining in place or being introduced at a national level. Finally, with regard to bad information or misinformation on products, borrowers will be better informed about the loans on offer in the future, as the Mortgage Credit Directive enhances the quality and comparability of pre-contractual information. The Mortgage Credit Directive also introduces rules on the conduct expected by businesses with a view to ensuring that the creditor, credit intermediary or appointed representative acts honestly, fairly, transparently and professionally, as well as introducing appropriate knowledge and competence requirements for staff of creditors and credit intermediaries. The new Markets in Financial Instruments Directive applies to investment services. It will improve investor protection for financial instruments by strengthening organisational requirements and the rules on the conduct of businesses for investment firms to minimise the risk of mis-selling of financial instruments. Specifically, it introduces product governance rules and enhances disclosure requirements vis-à-vis investors, for the first time. The deadline for transposition of these measures has not been reached yet. Hence, it would be premature to state at this stage whether and what new further measures would be needed.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, first of all, the Government of Spain is very concerned about everything that has happened on the subject of preferred products, these complicated products which, in the absence of information, caused many difficulties for many Spanish citizens, and also the issue of evictions, given that the crisis has mainly affected the most vulnerable sectors. I have to say, on the subject of preferred ones, which were basically sold between 2003 and 2011, and when the People's Party Government arrived, it encountered this situation even though many directives, such as the 2008 Markets Directive, and agreements, such as the 2011 Basel Directive, had warned the Socialist Government, which ruled Spain at the time, to take action and take action so that customers could be informed. It wasn't done. The Socialist Government at the time was reckless, lacked seriousness, and it was a popular government which, at the end of 2011 and early 2012, undertakes a whole series of legislative amendments – as the Commissioner has pointed out – so that these products are never mass re-marketed among small investors and, at the same time, initiates arbitration proceedings , in which, the Commissioner said so, more than 71% of those affected have reached an agreement. You work on the subject and it looks like you're on the go. On the issue of evictions, it was also a popular government that first protected vulnerable groups. Think that the executions and evictions carried out in 2014 had their origins in mortgages signed between 2005 and 2008, and it was the people's government that put in place conjunctural measures to protect the most vulnerable sectors – as the Commissioner has said very well – with debt restructuring, with the remove and also with the payment. In fact, it was one of the first governments to have established the payment. And it has also taken structural measures to ensure that it does not happen again in the future. In fact, thousands of families have benefited. Still, we're still working. What I am going to ask my Spanish colleagues is not to turn this very important debate into an electoral debate, because I believe that the victims of evictions and the preferred ones deserve other kinds of debates. (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: "blue card" question. – Mrs. You will be, it seems that you live in one reality and Spanish citizenship lives in another. Perhaps this is why he has had this slip-up related to electoral measures rather than talking about structural measures. Repeated European rulings have indicated that Spanish law is contrary to European foreclosure rules, as we have already denounced here by a crushing majority of Spanish MEPs in July 2014. Will the People's Party continue to embarrass us by unansting these sentences without prompting any modification...? The President interrupts the speaker.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: "blue card" response. – You may think it's okay or you'll find it wrong, but the facts are the facts. The Government of Spain, since it became aware of this, adopted conjunctural and structural measures. I warn you that cynicism is the weapon of the incapable to cover up his shames, which are his.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, Commissioner, the crisis has given us a lot of lessons and one of them is the disparate, unequal and, in many cases, insufficient protection that small users of banking in the European Union have. And in Spain, moreover, it has become a social drama. It is true that the Spanish Socialists do not right to respond to this situation in its early days and do not hide it, but we do not accompany ourselves and we will avoid this injustice which, to this day, remains a debt to Spanish society. This is also supported by the fact that Spanish society has contributed to the recapitalisation of banking with 107 billion euros, which clashes with more than four hundred thousand evictions since the crisis began, or with the seven hundred thousand small users or savers who saw their savings trapped, of which they have recovered one in three euros, because the removes represent between 30 and 70%, and even today more than three hundred thousand small savers remain trapped. To this end, it is true that the Government of Spain has introduced twelve legislative amendments, but all of them partial and with a clear will that something seems to change so that absolutely nothing changes: voluntary code of good practice for banks and requirements that do not meet a small part of those affected. This is demonstrated by facts such as no payment damages, that only 0.4% of social rent has been granted and that there are now 3.5 billion euros trapped in abusive mortgages.  We say this and so does the judgment of the Court of Justice of the European Union, which states that, of Directive 93/13/EEC, Articles 3, 4, 5, 6 and 7 are breached in Spain. In addition, the Advocate General himself of the Court of Justice of the European Union, in his May 2015 report, says very clearly that the amendments made by the Government of Spain are clearly insufficient. Therefore, I ask that we do not put any more patches, that we do not make the Spanish people suffer any more. What we want is a general response. I ask the Commission to make a serious and rigorous analysis to adapt our legislation to that of the European Union and to eliminate the thousands of unfair terms that we have today, and to give a solution to the small savers who continue to have their savings trapped.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, mortgage legislation differs between the Member States of the European Union, with the result that there is a differentiation in the conditions for consumer protection and debt settlement. In Spain and Greece, there has often been no proper information for borrowers by banks and the terms of the contracts violate the rights of borrowers as consumers. Since the financial crisis, the situation in Spain has deteriorated, resulting in at least 700,000 citizens being victims of high-risk loans, while more than 350,000 exports have been recorded in the last six years. At the same time, the houses that came under the hammer came back into the ownership of the banks, which have been rescued from the money of the citizens of the European Union themselves, In Greece, red home loans reached 21 billion euros. There, the banks began selling the red loans to the well-known crows of the world market to aggressive hedge funds that are preparing to hammer, instead of lentil plates, the homes of the Greek people. In fact, with The 3rd, express procedures are also in place for auctions. More than 500,000 Greek borrowers are now at risk of losing their homes. Also, 70,000 Greeks who have taken out mortgages in Swiss francs are also at risk of losing their own homes. That is why, as a member of the Committee on Petitions, I call on the European Commission, in cooperation with the Central Bank, to take measures to protect the first residence and I call for an end to the auctions of houses in Greece and Spain. Thanks.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. –Madam President, Mrs Jourová, thank you for your detailed explanations. I believe that today we can - and we can all congratulate ourselves on this - that an oral question with a resolution has come here, to the House, and we are discussing it. It is great news, because it is not often that the Committee on Petitions, which is the open window of European citizens to this Parliament, is present in this way, and I believe that, since 2012 - since the Marrakesh Treaty – we did not have such an occasion. We are here because we have a purely European issue to talk about. We are talking about hundreds of thousands affected by abusive mortgage clauses and preferred ones. We don't know how many they are, it can be 300,000, it can be a million, two million... The point is that in the Committee on Petitions we received tens — almost a hundred requests — from European citizens who were affected by their rights as consumers in Spain.  That is why this is a purely European case because we are talking about European citizens living in Spain who, from the Committee on Petitions, are responsible for protecting, and whose requests we have to review and keep open, and above all it is up to us to build consensus, which is what I think we are looking for here.  Spanish consumers are in a situation of unprotection and helplessness in this area. This was stated by the Court of Justice of the European Union in its judgment, which justifies the intervention of the European authorities. In addition, we are talking about a purely European issue because it is a bad transposition of European directives. In fact, these requests denounced this poor transposition and non-compliance with a number of directives: both from the mortgage lending directive and from the directive on financial instruments , which governs the provision of investment services, including preferred ones, from the unfair terms in consumer contracts and, of course, from the market for financial instruments.  It seems to me that, although there are still many shortcomings in the effective and correct transposition of this directive in Spain, what we are here for is to prevent it from happening in the rest of Europe. Here's what's important. It doesn't matter where rights are violated. It does not matter in which country of the Union, in which Member State, it is up to us to monitor, denounce and ensure that we have the tools to guarantee European citizens that their rights are adequately protected. That is why we ask the Commission, in line with what Mrs Jourová has said, to keep a close eye on and to ensure that this situation is not going to be repeated.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: on behalf of theGUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, since the beginning of the crisis, according to the General Council of the Judiciary, 599 000 evictions have occurred in Spain and at least 700 000 people have been defrauded with preferred calls. Meanwhile, those same people paid the bank their ransom with cuts and austerity: with cuts in their wages, in their health care, in their education. That same bank that has returned only 5% of its bailout and which also accumulates thousands of empty homes and which, it must also be said, accumulates countless cases of corruption that have shattered public banking for the benefit of private banking in my country. That is why today we bring the voice of thousands of people here, to ask for justice and to enforce their rights, such as the right to decent housing and payment and also the right for this European Union to make legislation at European level against financial fraud.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, the Committee on Petitions to which I belong, in response to numerous citizen complaints, has often discussed the mis-application in Spain of European mortgage rules and financial instruments. The lack of consumer protection, scandalous and even criminal, has led in Spain to a real social drama. According to data from the Platform of Mortgage Affected, between 2008 and 2012 there were more than 160,000 evictions in Spain and, between 2012 and 2014, 100,000 more foreclosures were carried out, according to data from the Bank of Spain. The Council Directive of 5 April twenty-two years ago is strong on unfair terms: we cannot bail out banks if we do not protect consumers at their mercy.  While in countries such as the Netherlands 32% are invested in social housing, only 1% of the state's overall budgets are invested in Spain, according to Amnesty International data.  It is unacceptable that more than 700 000 clients without financial training subscribed, with the total inaction of the National Securities Market Commission, complex financial instruments and, because of their complexity, creators of deception. I have, Commissioner, three requests: first, for the Community institutions to encourage Member States to report on the complexity of financial instruments on the basis of, explicitly, clarity and transparency; second, that a consumer who cannot cope with his debt can settle it in whole or in part with the delivery of the house — the widespread application of the payment damage must be required; and, thirdly, for the Commission to replace the 22-year-old Directive with a more ambitious directive that actually protects consumers.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, although this is a purely Spanish case, I think it is important and right to have this debate in this House this evening in order to give due attention to the dozens of petitions that we have received and which highlight and bring us back to a very serious problem of truly unacceptable situations affecting hundreds of thousands of people who have been evicted.  These petitions ask us to take seriously and intellectual honesty a problem which, at the end of the day, does not only concern Spain, and I am referring to the excessive power of the banks, banks that have sold particularly risky financial products, in fact deliberately omitting details and deceiving consumers in this way. This is clearly unacceptable. We must fight and ensure that consumer law is protected as soon as possible, and the role of politics is clearly crucial in this.  Finally, I would like to stress that I very much hope that the right to a home will be clearly included in the resolution to be voted on in this plenary and that the Commission will take note of it as soon as possible.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: – Madam President, you all know that surely this debate should not be taking place here at the moment, and not only because it is essentially a national issue, as has been reiterated on many occasions and, moreover, as has been shown behind the speeches we have heard. And so much so knows that some Spanish left-wing Members present in this House have publicly blamed the use of this matter for their own and for electoral reasons. And I don't say it, they said it, and also in writing. But they're right about that. The left is making absolutely reprehensible use of what is the pain of citizens. The problem of preferred ones is an issue of concern and occupying the Government of the People's Party. It is a matter that should have been tackled earlier, but the previous government ignored it. On the contrary, legislative action has now been taken and arbitration procedures have been put in place which are assisting those affected, as the Commission itself acknowledges. But many of you don't care about this. They are more interested in who publishes the first press release, who makes the most noise and how to monetize it. Nor are they interested in seeing how from the Spanish Government we are working hard to solve the problem of those who have difficulty paying their mortgage dues – thousands of families in Spain – a painful situation, undoubtedly dating back to years prior to 2008, with this Government facing the problem with decision and courage. Legislative and aid measures for those affected are beginning to bear fruit. More than thirty thousand families have already benefited from the conjunctural measures taken in this legislature by the Government of the People's Party. But don't forget something: those who are suffering from this situation today are worth much more than a headline. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: "blue card" question. – It's embarrassing. I have no more words than that. As we listen to the barbarities of the People's Group, on this side of the bench we are filled with outrage. Don't you think you have already embarrassed the other Spanish groups and citizens enough with their inactivity, with their passivity in the face of the problem of evictions? Fortunately, it seems like this electoral or not, they only have two months left; two months for us to regain people's rights; two months to kick them out of the institutions; two months, for we are already tired of such shame and so much theft.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: – Madam President, our work in the Committee on Petitions, of which I am a member, focuses on the important role that the European Union plays in giving redress to consumers, this time in Spain but often in other countries, who have been affected by the irresponsible behaviour of others. One million British citizens live in Spain; many of them have mortgages. To restore the confidence of consumers across Europe, and to protect those taking out a mortgage in the future, we need to see all Member States pushing banks to act responsibly and provide clear, understandable and correct information. The implementation of the Mortgage Credit Directive will ensure a more transparent, efficient and competitive internal market that should provide a high level of consumer protection in the future. European Union citizens have sent us a strong and a clear call for action via those petitions that we received. We must now hear that call and ensure that their rights are protected.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Chair of the Committee on Petitions and its members for their efforts to ensure that the European institutions offer hope and solutions to many families. Excessive greed, abusive business practices, unfair and insufficient legislation, and a speculative and consequently failed model of development have created the drama of foreclosures.  Tens of thousands of families have lost housing and work in these years. Tens of thousands of endorsers, usually retired people who supported their children in the disaster, have followed the same path without even the so-called second-chance law solving a problem that creates situations of real social and humanitarian emergency. That is why, Commissioner, Brussels must oblige the Spanish authorities to make codes of good banking practice mandatory. Creditors and debtors must be encouraged to have equal weapons in insolvency resolution processes and modules relating to these problems must be incorporated into the field of education. Most of these dramas are the result of combining good faith from hands-on consumers and vendors with few scruples. Finally, I would like to point out that not all economies or all financial institutions work the same. In the first quarter of 2015 alone, 0.20% of mortgages on housing between 2003 and 2014 initiated an enforcement process in the Spanish State, in absolute numbers 17,786. The Basque Country, with 0.02%, is the region of the State, far from the others, with the lowest rate of executions. But these people shouldn't have gone through that suffering either. And while not complacency, the negotiating practices adopted there may be a benchmark for reducing tragedy, while laws put loan sharks in place.

name: Kostadinka KUNEVA
text: Madam President, hundreds of thousands of citizens in Spain, Greece and other Member States, such as Bulgaria, have been deceived in their attempt to obtain a right to residence by bank loan. Right recognized as inalienable, as early as 1948 in the founding declaration of the UN. And yet, 67 years later, the Commission is saying that it is not listening. Even if we have important institutional control tools, such as the consumer protection directives and the decision of the European Court of Justice on the Aziz case. The 398,000 exports - since 2008, in Spain - show that laws protecting borrowers from bank abuse are not being controlled. And the complaints coming to us from Bulgaria are of concern to us as to whether the European Banking Authority is supervising properly. In Greece, "red loans" look like a volcano about to erupt. 260,000 borrowers in the "red", most unemployed, without income, are anxious about whether they will have the luck of Spaniards after the end of capital controls, perhaps even earlier. When refugees leave their homes at the mercy of war and seek salvation in the heart of Europe, Europe itself cannot secure the home of its citizens. So let the Commission show that it does not see them as 'fine print' of bank contracts. Let him exercise serious control by giving life to the victims of the banking establishment.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen of the People's Party, you are already politically condemned by the public for allowing the human drama of evictions and, moreover, for making deaf ears to the one million thousand signatures of the ILP of the Platform of Those Affected by mortgage, which you did not want to attend to. And then it is very funny that they say that it is an internal matter when the Commissioner is telling them that there are indications that Spanish legislation does not comply with European legislation. Anyway, these are things you can't say. But, Commissioner, I would like to send you a very clear message. You have said that there are indications that the law, both civil and mortgage, does not yet meet European standards and directives despite legislative changes that have been made in 2013 and 2015. We can't wait any longer. Do not continue to tell us, as your representatives in the Committee on Petitions tell us, that they have a structured dialogue with the Spanish authorities and that they will find a solution, because in the meantime, what do we do?  What do we do with the 68,000 people who already suffered a foreclosure in 2014 and 19,000 this year? Nor can we wait for the 2016 directive, because time is running out and they are human dramas. Do something. If there are breaches and you have proof, please act.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Madam President, the 2008 subprime crisis in the US created chaos across the mortgage markets in the EU due to irresponsible lending. It was in that year that Spain’s housing bubble collapsed. This still continues to impact on many borrowers, who found their loans increasingly unaffordable, with a high level of defaults and foreclosures, which continues to rise. I genuinely sympathise with their plight. We need to have action to avoid eviction for those most in need – the young, the elderly and the young with families. What is needed is greater restructuring of the debt system. In 2011 the Commission created legislation for a fair single market for mortgages. Its focus was to ensure that all consumers getting a property or a mortgage on their home had adequate protection on risk. But, sadly, this is yet to be implemented fully across all Member States. Therefore, I call upon the Commission to ensure that Member States implement better lending practices and to lessen the stark contrast between practices in Member States, which leaves our citizens exposed.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: – Madam President, thank you very much, Commissioner, and thank you in particular to the Chair of the Committee on Petitions for her efforts to meet precisely all these demands of so many citizens; thank you very much for your tesson and for the way you've channeled the work.  Citizens are also consumers and we need to have confidence in those service providers that are essential in our lives, and banks fall into this category in a very clear way. In this plenary session we will address questions concerning different issues which are murky, especially in Spain, but which affect tens of thousands — hundreds of thousands in some cases – of European citizens. We are talking, for example, about the most dramatic case: that of complex financial products that defrauded, as we say, hundreds of thousands of small European investors.  We support this question — I hope that the Commission will give us the answer in an early way — and, of course, we will support any initiative to end unfair mortgage clauses and other situations that put weaker consumers in a position of helplessness.  We defend a comprehensive, competent financial sector, as we defend comprehensive, responsible and corruption-free political institutions. The financial products scam came because hundreds of thousands of customers were shown to be fixed income products, when in fact they were equities, therefore, with higher risk, and even perpetual status. Among the scammers are the elderly, alzheimer's sufferers, people with no financial knowledge. Look, he personally asked me for help after being ripped off by an unedyged widower, whose wife had been killed in a terrorist attack and who had bought the preferred ones with the compensation money without knowing what he was doing. Part of the problem has to do with an incorrect transposition of four directives," we said today. But another part had especially to do with the politicization of savings banks, the main contractors of fraudulently preferred holdings. Our party, in April 2013, brought to court the defense of the preferentists and the pursuit of their responsibilities.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: – Madam President, I think we are wrong if today the debate focuses on banking abuses. That the bosses of Santander or BBVA are thieves, we already know that. They have no scruples and seek only the maximum private benefit, we also know that. That is why the debate should focus on why governments—which are supposed to be at the service of the majority—have acted as servants of economic power. The debate should focus on why the Zapatero Government and the Rajoy Government have acted as accomplices to evictors and fraudsters; why, while bank managers were collecting scandalous salaries and pensions, 71 billion euros were earmarked in direct aid to save banks rather than create public banking. Wearing this T-shirt today is my way of thanking the activists of the Mortgage Affected Platform and the preferrs, because if evictions stop today, if there are some families recovering their savings, it is neither for this Parliament nor for the institutions of the Spanish State. It's because of his struggle.

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: – Madam President, I understand the inconvenience here today of the Spanish representatives of the PPE Group. That this question and this resolution have come to this House and done so after this long work of so many citizens and so many entities is in itself a good proof of the validity of Europe's need as a concept and as a useful reality for all of them. Now, a Europe, however, capable of combating injustice, of defending the dignity of its citizens with the only weapon of democratic decision.  The serious thing is that it's been necessary to get this far. The incomprehensible thing is that it remains so; that the Spanish state itself, its legislators, its governments, its banking institutions have not yet heard the cry that comes here today.  All this serves both in the case of mortgages on housing – the only firm asset for their owners – and in the case of the so-called preferred ones – with their aroma of confiscation of personal and family savings organized and practiced with impunity.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Madam President, this is a valuable action by the Committee on Petitions. If, however, we replaced the word Spain with the word Cyprus, everything else would apply, and far worse: both the ineffective application of European legislation and the inertia that is observed. The absolute numbers, in the case of Cyprus, may be small, but as a percentage, in another large Member State, they would be huge and this also concerns the writings, especially to borrowers, which exist in Cyprus to date, and where systematic and massively abusive provisions are used, such that they are either on the list of the European Directive or have been assessed by the European Court of Justice as Illegal.  Another huge problem is the so-called securities which have been sold to unsuspecting people, in violation of European legislation. Much of society was driven to withering and social alienation, even suicide. So that's why we're not just talking about agreements. And a suggestion to the Commissioner: an out-of-court mechanism for resolving banking disputes at European level I think will help the problem. (The President interrupts the speaker).

name: Jordi Vicent SEBASTIA TALAVERA
text: – Madam President, even if some are disturbed, this is a fully European matter. Even if we talk about the abusive practices of Spanish banks, which were armed – and armed – by legality, we are talking about a fully European issue. Because half a million families evicted and condemned to misery are European. Because the seven hundred thousand affected by the preferred scandal are also European. Because the banks that are applying these abusive and immoral conditions are European. Because the bailout funds, the hundred and seven billion we've received to save those same banks are European. It is European funds and with them we have saved the banks and we have had to implement those terrible policies of austerity that are still making our people more impoverished. And because the ruling that makes it clear that Spanish mortgage law is illegal is of the Court of Justice of the European Union. Therefore, Commissioner, Europe must act quickly. You have to avoid that legal makeup that the Spanish Government intends to sell us and that leaves 80% of those affected in the same situation of helplessness that they had. If Europe does not act, it does not deserve to have that role that we are all giving it here in this Parliament.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, I believe, considering the large number of petitions received by Parliament denouncing abusive terms in mortgage contracts and risky financial instruments in Spain, that it is appropriate to request the Commission to inquire effectively into whether there have been violations of fundamental rights and infringements of European legislation. We must be straightforward and take the lead to put an end to bank-related infringements of EU consumer rights laws in Spain. The situation in Spain is critical. Since 2008 more than 700 000 people have completely or partially lost their savings and nearly 400 000 have been evicted from their homes. The Spanish Government should act as soon as possible to put an end to this situation and to put forward initiatives to keep this from happening in the future.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: - Madam President, first of all, I would like to join in congratulating the Chair of the Committee on Petitions and also congratulating our colleague Soledad Cabezón, who has been working very hard in recent weeks to discuss this oral question to the Commission here.  The scandals that have affected our country have been wide in recent years. We are talking about mortgages, where there have been ground clauses, there has been an inability to negotiate between consumers and banks, but we are also talking about the preferred ones, which have ripped off many people, many elderly people, many young people in our country and, of course, we also talk about double commissions, which in recent weeks have been the subject of debate in our country.  It is important that the Commission intervenes in this matter; it is important to have a second-chance law that is able to restructure all kinds of renegotiation of consumer debts with mortgage financial institutions, and not just mortgages. That is why I ask the Commission to stop talking to a Government that does not want to take action and to start imposing that the law be complied with in our country

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: – Madam President, I was in the Spanish Government five years ago and I do not mind recognising that our Spanish mortgage legislation did not comply with the law. I don't mind acknowledging it, Mr. Mato, I don't care.  I do not mind recognizing that our financial products have been opaque, ours and those of many years ago and everywhere in Spain, by the way. I do not mind acknowledging that the Court has said that our legislation was not correct.  What I find unpresentable is that today we come here to talk about "my government" — four years after you are ruling — and say that the fault was solely the fault of the previous ones. It's just painful to hear it. It seems to me that things must be recognized and said that our legislation was wrong, that it must be changed; that there have been abusive clauses, yes, and they cannot be allowed. That is what I want the Commission to do because I am sorry that the People's Party continues to think that everything is fine and that they have already done everything. That's the hard thing.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Madam President, we prescribe the size of letters on cans that have meat products, we prescribe various labels and prescribe a lot of things, and about banks, banking services and banking products we have maximum patchwork. This is the case of Spain, the case of Greece, the case of Cyprus, but also the case of Croatia, where mortgage loans in Swiss francs destroyed citizens. Classic banking fraud. Small, fine print, nowhere is there a regulation about what letters should be when banking loans are taken out, but on meat cans and the origin of the meat and goods that are in these cans, that's where we prescribe something. It is in this context that we need new legislation and we need to make it clear that such banking fraud simply must not pass through the European Union.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: – Madam President, the fight against evictions and the struggle of people affected by the preferred ones – for the theft of the preferred ones – clearly highlight the tragedy of many thousands of families who lost, are about to lose or continue to lose their homes and also those families to which the banks stole the savings of their entire lives or a very important part of their lives. But this was done with the collusion and complicity of the Spanish government.  We have all seen how banks have been ized and people who dare to demand justice are blamed, penalized and repressed. We have witnessed in the Spanish State the violent expulsion of families from their homes and also of the police burdens on the people who were protesting against the preferred ones.  It's time to do justice. We call on the European Commission and the European Parliament to put an end to bank abuses, to reverse austerity policies... (The President interrupts the speaker.)

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, as I said before, EU legislation must be transposed and enforced in a satisfactory way so that the law fulfils its purpose. Clear information provided to consumers, to increase their protection, is essential. I agree with what Mr Polčák said, that preventive measures are very important and that they may sometimes be more efficient than certain hard regulation, but there must be a smart combination of both types of measure. As I said, we are also analysing the reply from the Spanish authorities which we received in June regarding the code of civil procedure, including its rules on mortgage enforcement proceedings and their conformity with the Unfair Contract Terms Directive. If the reply proves to be unsatisfactory, we shall take appropriate action without delay. I would like to reassure you of my commitment to guaranteed procedural protection for consumers. Whenever consumers appear before the courts they must enjoy all the procedural safeguards that are guaranteed by EU consumer law and by the case law of the Court of Justice. To conclude, some of you asked about the rules on insolvency. I would like to assure you that we are working on the proposal on the principle insolvency rules, including for private persons. We should propose this new piece of legislation next year.
