name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Writing. – The outbreak of the economic crisis in 2008 caused the collapse of the real estate market in Spain. Previously, people were sold high-risk financial instruments to finance their homes by their savings banks without educating them in detail about their credit transactions as consumers. Hundreds of thousands of people have since left their homes, been driven to ruin and several hundred even committed to suicide. Both Spanish and European courts have found unfair terms and practices in Spanish mortgage law. Tens of thousands of people have lost their homes as a result of this legislation and have been forcibly evacuated. This practice continued after the 2013 ECJ ruling. It is also important to promote social housing in Europe, which is very weak in Spain. There must also be the possibility of registering a private bankruptcy as a last resort throughout Europe. This possibility does not currently exist in Spain. This needs to be changed. We need European minimum standards for private bankruptcies.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on: - the oral question to the Commission on export control of dual-use products after the hacking team revelations, by Marietje Schaake, on behalf of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe (O-000094/2015 - B8-0756/2015) (2015/2882 (RSP)), - the oral question to the Commission on Export Control of Dual-Use Products after the Hacking Team revelations, by David Martin and Alessia Maria Mosca, on behalf of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats group in the European Parliament (O-0000099/2015 - B8-0759/2015) (2015/2882 (RSP)), and - the oral question to the Commission on Export Control of Dual-Use Products after the Hacking Team revelations , by Tiziana Beghin and Rolandas Paksas, on behalf of the Europe of Freedom and Direct Democracy Group (O-000102/2015 - B8-0760/2015) (2015/2882 (RSP)).

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: author. – Madam President, due to the hacking by Hacking Team we now know that companies’ tools allow users to monitor and record a person’s every digital move. Think about that. Leaked internal documents demonstrate that these tools were marketed and sold to the governments of countries the human rights records of which have been criticised by the EU, including Azerbaijan, Bahrain, Egypt, Morocco and Uzbekistan. We need EU rules to know the impact such EU-made systems have here at home and in the rest of the world, and to prevent exports to human rights violators. Commissioner, we need clear answers. Has Hacking Team violated EU sanctions against Russia and Sudan by selling systems that can be used to violate the human rights of journalists, political opponents and human rights activists, as the hacked and leaked documents suggest? More precisely I am referring to whether Article 2(1) of Regulation No 428/2009 should have applied. Did Security Council Resolution 1556 apply to Hacking Team and similar systems? The sanctions regime established under Article 4 of Regulation No 428/2009 includes an embargo on software and technology that can be used for civil or military purposes. I would like to know whether the Commission can guarantee that Member State authorities are implementing international obligations and doing so using the same yardstick. While this particular company may not survive this particular hack and this situation, the technology that they make is part of a wider industry and it continues and the market remains largely unregulated. Transparency and accountability are needed with regard to the sales of invasive dual-use tools that endanger people. Internal policies and self-regulation simply do not suffice. We need to ensure that our policies in foreign affairs and human rights are credible, and that they are not undermined by unregulated trade that happens at the same time.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, with the oral question that we have presented, we call on the Commission to start again from the joint declaration by Parliament and the Council last June in order to continue to strongly call for a decisive modernisation of Regulation (EC) No 428/2009 on dual-use products.  There are two general principles which form the basis of the matter which need to be highlighted because they go beyond the specific case to which our request refers. The European institutions, especially when it come to human rights, must ensure that the rules that must apply to everyone and everywhere are respected and that strict controls are carried out that are capable of punishing those who do not comply with them. The Hacking Team case cannot go without consequences, but we must not be content to punish companies guilty of unlawful espionage and violations of minimum freedoms. The real problem is not Hacking Team or the next company that will give the way to talk about the issue again, the problem lies in a weak regulation not concerted with other countries and that is too easily circumvented.  We are not credible if we claim to protect cybersecurity and human rights in distant countries, while at the same time allowing our companies to market with these same states some of the products that are banned precisely because they violate these same human rights. The sale of surveillance technologies is too little regulated and action at Community level is urgently needed, although it can only be a first step towards an overall global modernization based on the Wassenaar Agreement.  It is essential for the European Union to be at the forefront of this battle of civilisations in order to prevent the extraordinary technological innovations that are accompanying our time from becoming weapons in the hands of a few to the detriment of the weakest.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to remind you that Hacking Team is a company in Milan, Italy, which deals with cyber espionage and has developed a new generation of viruses capable of spying on and controlling PCs and smartphones, designed to target criminals and terrorists but, if in the wrong hands, also activists, human rights defenders and journalists. In Italy the software was used by law enforcement, but the real business the company did by selling them to Sudan, emirates, Colombia, Morocco, Kazakhstan, Lebanon, Egypt, Russia, Mexico and others, violating the law, but above all human rights. And we know all this because, ironically, the Hacking Team was hacked. Its state-of-the-way spying software was stolen from a cyberattack, with all the risks that come with it. I have just heard what Mr Moscow said and I wanted to add one detail: to sell this software to regimes and dictators we needed the authorisation of the Ministry, an authorization obtained thanks to pressure from the Italian Prime Minister, that is, Matteo Renzi, and it is not I who says this, but the chairman of Hacking Team himself in an email intercepted and published on WikiLeaks. Congratulations, My colleague, I very much appreciated your fine words of condemnation, but now I would like you to say these words to the journalists arrested by the regimes with which you have done business. Then I would like to understand why, you who are in government in Italy, have not blocked the authorizations for the sale of these software? Talk about human rights, but do business with dictators. You are the perfect expression of your party's coherence. These surveillance tools are part of dual use, dual use, because they are not technically weapons of war, but they can become in the wrong hands. A compromised computer is more useful than a spy satellite; for this reason an authorization is needed to export these software, especially to un democratic countries, authorizations that the Hacking Team has deliberately ignored or obtained too easily from the Italian ministry. How does the Commission intend to solve the problem of the application of European law on dual-use instruments, especially those relating to computer surveillance? How do you think a new Hacking Team case can be avoided?

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, when documented reports first emerged four years ago that companies based in the EU had been involved in the supply of cyber-surveillance technologies which may have been misused in connection with violations of human rights the Commission immediately took action. It is indeed a key concern that the export of cyber-surveillance technologies could be misused for supporting oppressive regimes or the violation of human rights. Firstly, in late 2011 and early 2012 respectively, the EU arms embargoes on Iran and Syria were both updated to include prohibitions on the export of interception technologies for internet and telephone communications. Secondly, the EU and its Member States promoted, in a timely way, multilateral controls on certain surveillance technologies, notably in the relevant multilateral forum known as the Wassenaar Arrangement. In December 2013 an agreement was reached to control internet surveillance equipment and intrusion software. The Commission followed up quickly to implement this international agreement and adopted a Commission delegated regulation in October 2014 ensuring that the export of those technologies is controlled. Those technologies fall into the category of dual-use items. These are wide-ranging categories of goods, software and technologies normally used for civilian purposes, but which may have military applications or may contribute to the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, such as nuclear materials, electronics or navigation systems. The current EU export control system for dual-use items allocates the responsibility for assessing export transactions involving these products to national competent authorities. However, the Commission monitors and supports the consistent implementation of the controls by Member State authorities. To that effect it set up in September 2014 a surveillance technology expert group with Member State experts, which has been meeting on a regular basis since its establishment. In addition to that immediate reaction, the Commission recognised in 2014, in its communication on the export control policy review, that although the EU export control system is robust and effective, it cannot remain static and must be upgraded in order to face new challenges associated with new technologies of concern. This communication identified options for an ambitious modernisation of the system. This includes options to address human security issues as the ones we are discussing here today. The Commission is now conducting a public consultation and will finalise the impact assessment on those review options with a view to presenting, as appropriate, proposals to upgrade the EU legal framework in early 2016. As regards the incriminated exports’ compliance with the regulations in place at the time, the Commission has obtained assurances from the Italian authorities that the exports from Hacking Team did not violate applicable sanctions and export control regulations. It should be noted in this respect that controls on intrusion software became effective in the EU only on 1 January 2015.  The Commission has taken note of concerns regarding possible unintended effects of controls on security testing tools which could possibly hinder research and has initiated dialogue with Member States, industry and NGOs to further assess the need to adjust some of the recent controls. The Commission notes that the introduction of controls in the area, which to date has not been subject to export controls, will require efforts to raise operators’ awareness.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, on 24 November 2014 I spoke in this House to request a revision of our legislation on exports of dual-use products. Today, almost a year later, I'm sorry to say that we're still at pretty much the same point. Even worse, because last July the case of the European company Hacking Team, specialized in the commercialization of devices, technologies and surveillance software, was uncovered. Technologies that are being used to commit privacy violations in third countries and are used by some governments as tools to suppress and violate the human rights of journalists, political opponents, bloggers and human rights defenders. According to the leaked internal documents, this European company sold its surveillance and espionage products to governments and intelligence services in countries whose human rights practices have been repeatedly condemned by the Union. We cannot allow any European technology to be involved in human rights abuses in third countries. There is a growing commercialization of these technologies, but the truth is that the regulation to which this market is subjected is frankly scarce. That's why we demand more transparency and accountability regarding the sale of these dual-use devices that invade people's privacy and privacy. Internal due diligence policies and self-regulation efforts have shown that they have been absolutely inadequate. We continue to expect legislation that improves and tightens controls on these exports. Modern and effective legislation, capable of adapting to rapid technological and scientific changes. The European Union's convictions of human rights violations of privacy in third countries will lack any credibility if no action is taken to prevent such things from happening. The coherence of our foreign and trade policy is at stake. We can't wait any longer for that improvement legislation.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr The EU's policy on peace and security should be about development, trade, human rights and much more – and that is connected. That is why it often clashes when we talk about the export of armaments. By that I mean not only conventional arms exports, but also the risks of dual-use products, which are not always regulated today. I am also talking about the risks associated with exporting all this material to non-democratic states. Many times it is material that can lead to greater security, but which, if they fall into the wrong hands, can threaten both our security and human rights to the same extent as conventional weapons. It is particularly risky to export information technology and monitoring equipment to regimes that violate human rights. This has been demonstrated, among other things, by the Arab Spring, such as Nokia and Siemens, which helped the Iranian regime to persecute democracy activists. Swedish Ericsson chose to provide the Syrian regime with telecommunications equipment when the confrontations began, which meant that opposition figures could be easily tracked by the regime. German and British technology was used against demonstrators by the regimes of Bahrain, Egypt and Tunisia. Democratic organisations with official EU support have been spied on, they have been infiltrated, members have been tortured, killed or imprisoned. That is why it is very important that we take up the export of sensitive information and communication technology to these countries. I hope that the Commission's review will also look at finding a very strict and consistent regulatory framework to prevent rather than come and put out fires.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: – The European Union maintains a high standard in the protection of human rights and freedoms and strives to set an example for the whole world in their promotion, respect and respect. We are therefore concerned about the case of the Italian hacking team, which sells tools enabling governments and other users to monitor and record every digital movement of an individual, including countries that have been repeatedly criticised by the EU for its human rights record, such as Egypt, Morocco, Uzbekistan and Bahrain. The European Commission must therefore respond promptly, as the market in which the firm in question operates is currently very little controlled and largely unregulated. By doing so, we will send a clear signal to our partners that violations and non-respect for fundamental human rights and freedoms will not be tolerated in the European Union. The European Commission must also find a way to stop the sale of products that allow such human rights violations in relation to the subject. I also consider it necessary for us to think seriously about the budget of the European Network and Information Security Agency, which has been suffering from financial undersized for a long time and is thus unable to respond to similar situations up to date.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, it is absolutely unacceptable that we permit hacking companies to sell to authoritarian regimes when we know that their products could be used to spy on journalists, dissidents and citizens, thereby using high-definition (HD) technology to facilitate gross human rights abuses. Even if they do not sell directly to authoritarian regimes, they are almost as guilty by letting dangerous tools fall into the hands of malicious states or non-state actors. If that happens, their failure to keep track of exports of their own software means that they do not care if their technology is misused and do not care about the vulnerability of those who defend human rights. It is vital that we find a way to control the export of these tools that could be used to target human rights activists and pro-democracy supporters at home and abroad.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, firstly thanks to Marietje Schaake and the other colleagues who have done great work in this rather complicated area, and thanks also to the Commission for the detailed statement a few moments ago. I suppose hacking is the big enemy of the digital world and technological advancement, and it is very difficult to come to terms with. It reminds me a bit of doping in the sporting world: it is almost impossible for the enforcers to keep ahead of the dopers, and I suppose the same could be said here. Nevertheless, we have to try, particularly in relation to the issue raised here tonight: the sale of software equipment to dictators, etcetera. That cannot be tolerated under any circumstances. Everything must be done to try and stop it, and particularly to ensure that the rights of journalists and human rights activists, etcetera, are not violated. So I think a few things are needed: the first is strong regulation and the second is stronger penalties.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: – Mrs Jourová, in the previous debate, I raised a question for the protection of Greek borrowers, in Swiss francs. There are 70,000 families at risk of losing their homes.  Since I have not heard you say anything about this, we must take this seriously and I would point this out because a particular political group is launching a separate voting procedure on two amendments that I have tabled to protect Greek borrowers in Swiss francs, and it is important.  On the subject of this particular hacking company, the unacceptable first of all is that there is a company that makes software to make hacking. This must be denounced, because this should not be allowed. The second point is that this company gives or has been robbed of this software, which now reaches organisations, states, which violate human rights and should, in this case, take serious measures by the Commission, so that we do not have a violation of human rights with a software that relies purely on hacking.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: " Mr. President, products that may have dual purposes are a topic we have already discussed in this house, in this term, but it seems to me that we have not gone much further. Namely, this case of Hacking Team had to happen in order to get this topic back on the agenda and to reopen a number of issues of our general security, especially personal security, and those of us who live in the European Union, especially those who live in countries where these technologies are sold. They can then be used in various other countries, they do not have to be used only in those countries where they were sold.  Let me remind you that this is also a danger for those of us who live in the European Union. We can create enormous, terrible problems for ourselves. In this context, I expect that the Commission, not only because it has submitted everything to the Member States, but also because it also has part of the responsibility, will come with concrete ideas and proposals to this Parliament.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Mr President, the Hacking Team revelations show up some serious failures. They show a failure by the Italian Government to hold firm on banning the export of this dangerous technology, and a failure of common sense, decency and basic morality in those who failed to consider the impact of their actions. This spying software has been sold even to Saudi Arabia. Have we forgotten that this is the country which started to flog Raif Badawi, which beheads people on the flimsiest of evidence, and proposes to behead and crucify Ali Mohammed al-Nimr for protesting against the Saudi Government when he was just 17? Yet, even in the UK, we seem to consider these people to be our friends. We sell them equipment too. When the Saudi Arabian King died, we flew our flags at half-mast. Perhaps we too in the UK need to take a good, hard, long look in the mirror.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I would like to say that, like any thing, it has a back and a cheek, especially for dual-purpose items. Here, the back and the cheek, I think, also depends on the progress of our allies. At a time when, of course, European businesses should be monitoring the desired development, employment, competitiveness and dual-use items, that is, if they really fulfil the purpose of developing Europe in this field of competitiveness.  But at the moment when this is not the case, of course, such goods are starting to bother us, and at the moment when European businesses are being pushed out in this way by other competing undertakings of our coalition allies, especially from NATO countries, that is, I think, one of the things that would probably bother us if this activity were not coordinated. I thank the Commissioner very much for her judicious approach. I will be following the public debate it has set itself for this task, and I will be very hopeful that the rules will be modernised and authorised.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank my colleagues for a relatively good and factual debate. The question of violation of the right to use things private is a question of human integrity. The question of human integrity is always a moral question.  I do not think that any regulation on the part of the European Commission will ensure that such software is not sold to countries that have a human rights problem. I think it's a more moral question. Companies that can make quite a lot of money on special software should be able to understand and integrate this thing so that they do not have to sell it to countries that have human rights problems and violations.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, allow me to reiterate the Commission’s determination to take on the challenges posed by the export of dual-use cyber surveillance technologies. We have acted resolutely over the last few years and have taken unprecedented action to prevent exports that might be misused in violation of human rights. In this context we must ensure that export controls contribute to a broader policy perspective, along with other tools such as sanctions, in order to provide a progressive, proportionate and effective response.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The debate has been closed.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is one-minute interventions on important political issues (Article 163 of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: – Small and medium-sized enterprises form the backs of the European economy. They represent 99% of all European businesses and employ up to 75 million workers. For small businesses, it is necessary to simplify firms' access to finance, reduce administrative burdens and encourage people to set up businesses. One of the ideal tools that can motivate people to do business is the adoption of a directive on single-person limited liability companies, which makes it possible to set up a business in the Union through online registration with a minimum capital of EUR 1. Despite the fact that there are up to 21 million small and medium-sized enterprises operating in the European Union, there are still differences in legislation. It is crucial that we remove administrative barriers, use new digital technologies and exploit the full potential of our common market. This proposal to make business start-up significantly easier has already passed in the Committee on the Internal Market, and I believe that everyone who cares about reducing administration, simplifying life and using new technologies, as well as in this House ... (speaker interrupted by the President)... support this important initiative.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: – Mr President, 222 workers – the entire workforce – have lost their jobs in Sagunto as a result of the closure of the multinational Bosal after thirty years of activity. The plant has ceased to be a priority for the group to which it belongs, which has decided its liquidation without crediting losses. A closure that is therefore not motivated for economic reasons and which is fully fully permissive and very unfair in Spanish labour legislation. A solvent and profitable multinational that has refused to negotiate with trade unions a plan of viability and continuity of the plant. A company that has decapitalized the plant so that it does not have to deal with the debts incurred with its workers. A company that received public aid to settle in Sagunto, a town heavily punished by the loss of industrialization and industrial conversion of the 1980s.  I therefore ask the Commission to launch the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund and to help the regions that are suffering heavily from relocation and deind industrialisation succeed.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Mr President, my city of Sofia is facing an extremely big problem and this is the flooding of illegal economic immigrants. All these people are economic immigrants, because according to international norms and treaties, refugees must be housed in the nearest safe country, and according to international law such is Turkey.  Economic immigrants take over the center of Sofia and permanently change the image of this city. The main reason this happened is the presence of a camp for illegal immigrants in the very center of the capital of Bulgaria. These reception centers create numerous problems for nearby residents.  Migrants who receive refugee status and leave the centers cannot enter society and create closed religious and ethnic enclaves in the very center of the city. For now, these are several streets near the largest metropolitan market and the metropolitan center. But with each passing day, this enclave expands and takes over an increasing part of the city center. It's the same in the other two neighborhoods where there are similar centers.  Sofia no longer looks like a European capital and this process must stop. The Bulgarian authorities must immediately take measures for the removal of refugee camps near the border with Turkey, from where illegal economic immigrants pass by on a daily basis.

name: Nedzhmi ALI
text: – Mr President, recently all of us became witnesses to unfortunate events in Europe: a mass inflow of refugees from the Middle East and Africa, thousands of dead people and bitter divisions among the EU Member States over the migrants crisis. In this regard I would like to draw your attention to the responsibilities of Frontex, and those respectively of the Commission and the Council. In facing the emergency situation in the European Union, how the agency fulfils its mission to promote, coordinate and develop European border management in line with EU fundamental rights is of the utmost importance. I would like to call for the urgent implementation of an effective strategy and for the preparation of a new strategy, well before 2017, in relation to the announcement by Frontex during the hearing this year. In this context, the following must be answered: how, in the most efficient and effective way, can the agency fulfil its task according to the new strategy developed on the basis of a changed reality in the regions. These issues are becoming more and more important nowadays in view of the worsening security environment and the problems of migrants coming to the EU. There is an urgent need for a common European position and a long-term approach. Frontex needs to improve strategy, have a flexible reaction and produce real results in the implementation of the EU’s executive-branch responsibilities.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: Mr President, I have stressed, many times in the past, the Union's responsibilities in creating and maintaining this unprecedented humanitarian crisis with regard to the refugee crisis. But despite the death toll, Europe is, in fact, refusing to deal with it.  Since the beginning of the year, Greece and Italy have accepted more than five hundred thousand refugees and by the end of 2016, the UNHCR plans to exceed one and a half million. And today we are talking about relocating just 160,000 to Europe, to a divided Europe, with Member States erecting walls and wanting to go to court.  In the meantime, we have not taken any measures to ensure safe access for refugees and we count daily victims in the Mediterranean. Ladies and gentlemen, winter has come and requires radical and immediate measures, otherwise we will also be counting victims on land.  The bet of dealing with the humanitarian crisis must be won. There is no longer the dilemma of 'what Europe we want'. The refugee crisis is testing us all. If we fail, there will be no Europe.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: – Mr President, I would like to remind the House that elections to the Parliament of Catalonia were held eight days ago. With a 77.46% share, independence has won 72 seats out of 135, or four over the absolute majority, and received 47.8% of the vote. Such an outcome must open the door so that Catalans can express, with all the guarantees, their willingness to become an independent state in Europe. For example, in Quebec twice, and in Scotland, referendums were once held after independence parties had won fewer parliamentary votes than they did a week ago by Catalan independence. I hope that the European Parliament will follow developments closely and that one day it will support, as it has in other cases, the imposing democratic cry that is being lived in Catalonia.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, what was supposed to be a peaceful picnic last Saturday to protest against the HIGH-SPEED TRAIN saw moments of unacceptable violence against citizens by Italian security forces, events that were distorted and falsified in the media.  I was present with a delegation made up of some of my colleagues from the 5-Star Movement, the GUE Group and the Green Group in Val Susa for two days to listen to the reasons for the 'no' vote and to support them against this great unnecessary and imposed work which is the TAV. Useless, because behind the false myth of progress and innovation it wants to support a project that has no sustainability in terms of costs/benefits, in environmental terms, in social terms and in terms of mobility. We are also calling for transparency in the funding that is being disbursed for these works.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Digital technologies are ushering in a paradigm shift in the global economy and having a significant impact on Europe's competitiveness. Digitisation affects all sectors of the economy. According to Commission estimates, a functioning digital single market will generate an additional GDP growth of €415 billion. Three-quarters of these come from traditional industries, not FROM ICT manufacturers. I will just say: Industry 4.0. We are talking about the absolute growth market. The big data sector alone is growing at 40% per year. This is seven times faster than the IT market, which is also a fast-growing market. What should be done to get Europe in the fast lane? The digital infrastructure must be expanded. We need EUR 34 billion by 2020 to develop broadband networks. Innovative standards for interoperability must be set, which must be technology neutral. We need new training curricula. A regulatory framework for data protection and data security must also be set. 22% of Europeans do not trust the operator of search engines, social networks and e-mail services.  Europe must regain its digital sovereignty and catch up with the US in competition.

name: Diane DODDS
text: – Mr President, currently talks are ongoing to resolve serious problems with devolved government in Northern Ireland. This is no contrived crisis, but has come about as a result of a murder on the streets of Belfast. The Chief Constable of the Police Service of Northern Ireland has linked that murder to the Provisional IRA – a paramilitary organisation linked to one of the parties in Northern Ireland and, indeed, a party whose representatives sit in this Parliament, namely Sinn Féin. Such an event cannot be swept under the carpet. It cannot simply be ‘business as usual’ in Northern Ireland. We want to see progress made in the talks towards ending all paramilitary activity in Northern Ireland. These groups should never have existed and we must see their grip on communities finally ended. This murder took place at a time of great financial uncertainty facing Northern Ireland. That financial uncertainty, too, is caused by the failure of Republicans and Nationalists to live up to their agreements.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I rise tonight to ask the Commission to ensure that there is fair competition, particularly for indigenous companies that are trying to expand across Europe and avail of the single market. For instance, a company from my own country, Supermac’s, was founded by Pat McDonagh a number of years ago and now has 100 outlets in Ireland, employing about 3 000 people, but when it tried to expand abroad it came up against the multinational giant McDonald’s, which is challenging firstly its right to use the name ‘Mac’. There are millions of Macs around the world, so surely McDonald’s should not have the sole right to that brand. Secondly, the same McDonald’s is under investigation at European level for tax avoidance – allegedly EUR 3.7 billion – and this is being used to keep competition at bay. It is very important that we establish fair competition and a level playing field for all businesses, and that all businesses pay their fair share of tax.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: – Mr President, we talk a lot at this time about solidarity and it is normal to do so. Romania is in solidarity with its European partners and it is normal for this attitude to be matched by solidarity in rights. This would be fair and in line with the values and principles of the European Union in which we all believe. Solidarity means rights and obligations respected and assumed to the same extent by all Member States. I believe that Romania's accession to the Schengen area will increase the security of this area. We are a responsible EU Member State. Moreover, Romania is already acting as a de facto Schengen state, if we look at the model in which our country secures its borders. I call on European political leaders to take into account the efforts and results of the Romanian authorities and to abandon the political objections that have so far stopped Romania's entry into Schengen. Thanks.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the Greek people are once again experiencing the anti-social attack of the loan lenders and the troika who imposed the Third Memorandum. A memorandum that reduces wages and pensions, dissolves the insurance system, makes a tax break on the private property of the middle class, raises taxes at the expense of farmers and prepares the plundering of public property.  For our part, we have demonstrated our consistent and undying anti-monumental action, in the European Parliament and in Greece, and we will continue our fight against the troika and the Greek memorandum of understanding of the SYRIZA, ANEL, New Democracy, PASOK, Potami parties, which voted for Memorandum III.  The anti-monumental citizens whom I represent here in the European Parliament say that we will, as always, be present in the new social struggles. We therefore call on the thousands of consistent fighters of the anti-monumental, patriotic, democratic arc to join us and to thicken the ranks of our political movement of anti-monumental citizens. The fight continues.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Mr President, today the OECD released the 2015 Final Report on Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS). I broadly welcome what is in this report, and in this context I am pleased to see that Ireland will be one of the first EU countries to introduce new rules on country-by-country reporting. However, I wish to highlight something called the ‘principal purposes test’ which is in Action 6 of BEPS. This test means that if one Member State believes that the principal purposes of various transactions of a particular company were to obtain tax treaty benefits, then they could deny those benefits. Therefore, you could have a situation between Member States – this is in terms of tax treaties – where, for example, Germany could have different arrangements with companies in the UK than they might have in Ireland. My question is: how does this sit with freedom of establishment, which is one of the basic freedoms in the Treaty? Has the Commission looked at the possibility that these rules could violate the Treaties? What we need are common standards against treaty shopping, not arbitrary case-by-case decisions by Member States.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: – Mr President, the newly opened Alvarez Cunqueiro de Vigo hospital centre is a clear example of the chaos and precarization of the privatization of health in my country in Galicia. With the opening of this hospital, the Galician Government closed all or part of three hospitals, which means that, for example, the number of beds is the same or that hospital emergencies are completely collapsed. Non-health services have been fully privatized and also part of the functions of wardens and wardens, for example, which means a very large loss of quality in services and also the loss of many jobs. All users, and some of the staff, are also required to pay to park when they arrive at this hospital. I would like to call on the Commission to put an end to austerity policies, to stop endangering people's health and lives, because austerity kills.

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: – Mr President, on Wednesday I will not be able to do so (he uttered this phrase in Catalan), and I therefore now form the reflection he would have wanted to make live to King Felipe VI. My respect for your figure and your person. His reign derives from a Constitution that was proclaimed democratically and which I voted for myself. But I would also like to express to you my deep disappointment — better, outrage — at the repeated denial that the institutions of the State make of my democratic rights as a citizen, as a Catalan, as Spanish and as a European. Now the 1978 constitution is being used, the same one that guarantees dynastic continuity, to deny us the right to decide our future. Catalonia, as you know, is an old European nation that is about to be a new state, equally European. Look at the results of September 27. My disappointment and that of so many others has become collective determination and will soon become so in the form of an unppealable democratic decision, under the watchful eye and verification due from this House and from all the European institutions. I hope so. I ask the King of Spain, therefore, to respect and enjoy that my right and the decision freely made by Catalan society as a whole.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, for two months now, the citizens of Sanremo, liguria, have been guarding against the landfill called Lotto 6.  It is called Lot 6 because there are already five landfills in that area and all of them, thanks to the bad management, are destroying the territory and the existence of those who have the misfortune to live nearby. In twenty years a local mother has had to deal with seven cases of cancer in her family and in fact it is no coincidence that the most tenacious opposition comes precisely from mothers.  Mr President, does it seem normal to you that in order to house waste for only three years it is necessary to blow up an entire hill? Does it seem normal to you to violate the directive on biodiversity, the directive on soil and water contamination without considering the landfill directive that Italy has already violated several times? That is why I would like to denounce here, before you, this umpteenth speculation because just today permission has been granted for the use of explosives for the construction of the site. The citizens have been in continuous care for two months, day and night and they have never grown tired and will never get tired because it is a struggle for survival, it is their lives that are at stake. I appeal to the institutions and the mayors: have the courage to look the citizens in the eye and give them an answer now.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we will soon be hosting the King of Spain here, just days after the Catalans voted quite unequivocally in favour of independence. It is not clear at this time whether and how the Spanish king will speak of Catalonia, but it can be assumed that this will not be much more than the bare an unwilling Madrid tone with which the Spanish authorities have so far begged Catalan autonomy. Ladies and gentlemen, I come from Flanders, which itself was governed by Spanish kings for more than a century and a half. I would like to call on the European Union not to continue to take the wrong side and to slowly learn to realise, but rather as soon as possible, that there is no option for European cooperation in the 21st century but to recognise the autonomy of peacefully independent parts of the current Member States.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: - Mr President, Fellow Members, I would like to thank you for your support. In recent months, Europe's political and public life has been dominated by the migration crisis and the situation in Ukraine has been overshadowed. On 25 October, local elections will be held in Ukraine, with high hopes for Hungarians in Transcarpathia. However, Ukraine, which has voiced European orientation and democratic reforms, is once again making obstacles to the representation of national minorities, including Hungarians, who live in the country. I would like to express my outrage and protest against the discriminatory and unlawful decision of the Ukrainian Central Election Commission, which has mosaicically shaped the electoral districts in Transcarpathia, the western westernest county of Ukraine, where Hungarians make up 12% of the population, in order to prevent Hungarian representatives from entering the county council. These decisions violate international and European commitments, the Ukrainian Constitution and the law. Nor is it in the th of devolution reform. I therefore believe that the European Union must pay close attention to the fact that the elections are conducted in a clear way according to European standards.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, for many it may seem hard to believe that almost a quarter of European citizens live on the edge of poverty. Of these, about 55 million are unable to feed on a normal meal every day.  Europe is turning into a land of paradoxes. Between 90 and 120 million tonnes of food are destroyed each year. Waste becomes a habit, while studies show that one in three children is either overweight or obese. We invest in health, in studies, in prevention, while almost 10% of EU citizens are unable to feed properly.  We have proposed allocating half a million euros to develop those practices that limit food waste. That is why I believe that it is the duty of all Member States and the European Commission to work together to increase the area of food redistribution. Europe is facing new challenges today. The number of refugees is constantly increasing and now is the time to think about everything we can do to limit waste and use resources for poor families.  My message is this: stop food waste, inform your citizens, come up with solutions to redistribute food resources that are otherwise destroyed. Thank.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Vladimir Putin has pledged to work with the West to resolve the Syrian conflict. It is not clear to what extent this declaration is being implemented. One thing is certain that the promise itself made it easier for him to return to international diplomatic salons.  Traditionally, the Russian President, presenting carrots to the West, to my region, and especially to my country, had a pole. This stick was the extension of sanctions to fish processing, further sanctions on fish processing and Polish companies. This case has a serious aspect: the Federal Veterinary and Phytosanitary Supervision Service acted on behalf of the institutions of sovereign States within the Eurasian Union. It also has a comical aspect: sanctions have been imposed on a Polish company in my constituency that has not exported goods to Russia at all for more than two years.

name: Jozo RADOŠ
text: – Mr. President, the integration of the six Western Balkan countries into the European Union is a common interest. Better transport and energy connectivity between these countries will contribute not only to economic growth but also to their better understanding of each other. The inclusion of these countries in Europe's large transport TEN-T network will connect these countries with Europe, but will also connect member states with each other. Maintaining a high level of support for the citizens of these countries by including their countries in the European Union is certainly a very important added value on the path of these countries towards the ultimate goal, namely membership of the European Union.  I therefore call on the European Commission to further develop the connectivity plan developed in cooperation with these countries, in particular to work with a commitment to deliver on the ten priority projects developed under this plan.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: – Mr President, on 30 September 2015 the Russian Federation started bombing Syria, claiming that the attacks are directed against Islamic State. However, according to independent media, the aerial campaign ordered by President Putin has mainly targeted the rebel groups opposing the regime of President Bashar al—Assad. This Russian intervention not being coordinated with the NATO-led coalition of Western and Arab states adds new dimensions to Syria’s now four-year-long civil war and to the refugee crisis faced by the EU. Not only do the airstrikes not improve the situation in Syria but they make it even worse, causing numerous civilian casualties and increasing the number of Syrian refugees seeking protection in Europe. Importantly, Russia openly refuses support for any refugees from the Middle East. All this demonstrates that President Putin is not interested in finding a political solution to the Syrian crisis. I therefore strongly urge all EU Member States and EU authorities to put pressure on Russia to stop this unilateral intervention and to engage in constructive cooperation with the international community to solve the Syrian crisis.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, Elcogas is a thermal power plant in Puertollano (Castilla-La Mancha) which employs more than a thousand and five hundred people. A clean coal plant, a pioneer throughout Europe in the capture of CO2 emissions, a power plant which, in the words of the Commissioner, Mr Cañete, is fully compatible with the objective of a low-carbon and sustainable energy union. Elcogas is employment, it is innovation, it is sustainability, but above all, it is a victim. Victim of a clumsy energy policy by the Government of Spain, which is able to throw billions of euros into sustainable investments and hundreds of thousands of jobs, precisely by designing an energy policy based on political vendettas. The Elcogas project convinces the Commission, convinces Vice-President Eef-Soviet, convinces Mr Cañete, and that is why, because he convinces them, I ask them to intermediate. We need your help to avoid closure. Twenty-five days from now, Elcogas will close. And to prevent this, they only need a political decision, a small budget aid, a decree to keep their doors open, to avoid the nightmare. Commissioners, help us avoid it.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Mr President, last week I returned from a monitoring mission in Greece, which checked seven priority projects financed by European Union subsidies. One of these projects was the unfinished digital cadastre. Greece is the last member country of the European Union that does not have a digital land register. It still uses a paper register, that is, individual plots, their positions and boundaries are not fully identified and described. Legal security is thus not ensured, the list is not completely complete and the existing landowners are not identified, and moreover, this also means the impossibility of using the environmental strategy, the use of natural resources and, above all, the good taxation of property. I consider this to be an incredible irresponsibility and one of the huge weaknesses of the Greek system, which has an impact on the lives of ordinary Greeks, but also on other European countries that subsidise Greece through bailout programmes. The Greek Government should take this project as an absolute priority and the Commission should contribute instructions to successful implementation instead of providing additional money.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: – On 17 September, the mayor of Duisburg, Mr Søren Link, made discriminatory comments on the address of citizens of Eastern European countries, in which he said, quote: "I am inclined to shelter twice as many Syrian refugees, but at the expense of getting rid of several Eastern Europeans". Despite the reactions he provoked, his comments continued in the same spirit, this time aimed at the citizens of my country Bulgaria.  I find such statements to be highly inappropriate, unnecessarily provocative and a growing divide among the citizens of the Union. This comes at a time when the European Union is facing a refugee and humanitarian crisis. We are expected to be united to face challenges that are highly likely to change our common future. How long will we divide into Eastern and Western Europeans? Populism in this direction or another is the way to destroy everything that has been built so far. I strongly do not accept Mr Link's statement and call on my colleagues and other European politicians to refrain from such statements, which bring increasing tension in the already tense environment.  I call on everyone to have a constructive dialogue in search of common solutions.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: – The World Federation for Family Planning IPPF, which is devoted, among other things, to the provision of abortion services, has been caught systematically, outrageously trading parts of the human body and whole dead foetuses. We found that this organisation has been paid considerable amounts by the European Commission for a long time. In recent years, it has been millions of euros, which is taxpayers' money. As early as 20 July, I asked the European Commission in writing whether it knew that such an organisation was valid, whether it knew that the IPPF was an organisation that violated, by such unprecedented action, a specific European law and all moral standards, and whether the Commission would condemn such a practice and end funding.  Three months have passed and the Commission is not responding. Will I and the entire public get answers? How long will he hesitate? When will the Commission finally cease cooperation with such an inhumane organisation?

name: Paul BRANNEN
text: – Mr President, last Friday the SSI steel works at Redcar in my constituency entered into receivership and 1 700 direct jobs, plus as many as 6 000 jobs in the supply chain in the local economy, are now under threat. The UK Conservative Government has refused to consider giving state aid, arguing that it would be against the Commission’s state rules for steel. However, as the Italian Government has shown at the ILVA steel plant in Taranto, Sicily, this is simply not the case. Labour MEPs believe the time has come for the European Union to come together to deal with the global challenge of Chinese steel dumping, and the time has come for the European Union to update the rules on state aid for a now-globalised world. At the planned summit on UK steel, Government, industry and all stakeholders must come together and find a sustainable, viable future for this vital sector, rather than issuing meaningless platitudes. A plan is currently on the table to save part of the steel works, and I believe the receivers need to prioritise that, thereby securing the maximum number of jobs on Teesside.

name: Romana TOMC
text: – I would like to talk about scholarships today. Youth unemployment is not only a technical problem affecting the deteriorating economic situation in a country, but it also has major impacts from a sociological point of view. Young people who are unemployed are becoming socially excluded. We have a good project to prevent this. We have the Youth Guarantee project and we cannot afford to fail in this project. But cooperation, interdepressive cooperation is crucial, and analysis shows that the school system, the ministries of employment and the economy are operating in their own way. Scholarships are an excellent instrument by which the state can regulate future supply and demand in the labour market, so scholarship policy should pay great attention to the state. It's not just about distributing money, it's about a thoughtful strategy. The Youth Guarantee also offers a lot of funding for scholarships. I therefore call on all responsible institutions to divide them in such a way that together we achieve the objectives set.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: – Mr President, last year an EU fund of EUR 100 million was diverted to a strange Hungarian cooperative called ESZOSZ that undertook an employment project for low-skilled people for a five-year period in one of the poorest regions of Hungary. The people who took part in that programme received their salaries only in the very first months, if at all, and then this mysterious cooperative disappeared into the dust. Two thousand eight hundred people and their families are now facing serious difficulties and are left without any income and even any hope. The Hungarian Government, which has played a decisive role in the escalation of the situation – with the official labour services taking an active part in the recruitment – has done absolutely nothing to help these vulnerable people. At the same time, as a consequence of anti-European propaganda by the Government, public opinion now tends to blame the European Union. Of course, there is also a strong suspicion of misuse of European funds. Therefore, here again, I urge the involvement of the Commission and the European Anti-Fraud Office, OLAF.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: This item on the agenda has been closed.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Mrs Virginie Rozière, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs, on the possibility of extending the protection of European Union geographical indications to non-agricultural products (COM(2014)0469 – 2015/2053(INI)) (A8–0259/2015).

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: Rapporteur. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we are approaching the first anniversary of this Commission and, in this first year of the year, we have heard the priorities that you have set out: support for SMEs, strengthening competitiveness, employment. We know and support the Commission's commitment to these priorities.  So, Commissioner, imagine that you have in your power the capacity to develop the competitiveness of several thousand companies, most of them SMEs, and that you can ease the financial burden on them and that they are forced to engage in fighting unfair competition - charges that sometimes account for up to 40% of their turnover. Imagine that you have in your power the opportunity to support the maintenance and development of employment in more than eight hundred production basins, by increasing job creation by 30%, as has been the case with food geographic indications. Imagine that you have a simple, very inexpensive way to offer visibility, export attractiveness to these companies, up to 25% of international demand.  That would be great, wouldn't it? You would definitely take a second of such a tool if it was available to you. Well I have good news: this tool exists and it is already in your hands. By immediately proposing a legislative instrument to recognise and support European artisanal production, you have at your fingertips a simple way to achieve the objectives I have just set out.  This is the striking conclusion of the in-depth work done by your services over the past several years. A very thorough study that you published in 2013 underpins the economic benefits I just mentioned. It is also the urgent demand of European SMEs and European consumers who have expressed themselves clearly in the responses to the consultation you carried out in 2014.  Finally, this is the message that I hope this Parliament will send to you tomorrow, asking you to include in the internal market strategy, which the Commission will make public in the coming weeks, the announcement of a legislative initiative for the extension of geographical indications to non-agricultural products from 2016.  Commissioner, for the time being, producers who wish to protect a non-agricultural geographical indication within the European Union must apply for it in every state, where possible, that is to say in barely half of them, or simply renounce such protection.  They risk, every day, the usurpation of their name by industrialists who jeopardize employment, economic vitality, the balance of territories that are sometimes fragile, simply because these industrialists use unduly a name that was until now a symbol of quality, history and know-how. Such unfair competition is not acceptable.  Extending geographical indications to non-agricultural products would be a strong political signal, a strong commitment by the European Union to make its local production shine. Because, more than products, these famous names - Murano, Bohème, Savile Row, Laguiole, Solingen - are the echo of a history, a culture. They represent European heritage, our heritage, which is why I invite all my colleagues to confirm tomorrow the broad vote in favour of the Committee on Legal Affairs on the report I am presenting here this evening.  Commissioner, the European Parliament is waiting for the European Commission on this subject but, through MEPs, much more importantly, it is the European consumers who are waiting for you, the European SMEs that rely on you, the European citizens who are watching you.  Show them that you are responding to their concerns, that you are providing them with solutions. Commissioner, don't disappoint them.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I fully support what the rapporteur has said. I think it is so clear that we could wonder why it did not happen until now. Certainly, geographical indications for agricultural products have been very important. I saw in my own constituency in Waterford a food product called a ‘blaa’. It is a bread roll made in a unique way. By getting geographical indication it has increased its marketing opportunities and become far more widely known. Now everybody who goes to Waterford wants, number one, to have a Waterford blaa. The same could apply to non-agricultural products. To take Waterford again as an example, there is the world-famous Waterford crystal. Its trophies are used in some of the big sports competitions in the world. It went through hard times recently, but I think that if it got geographical indication that would be a huge boost to it. So this is a tool, as the rapporteur has said, which we should utilise to grow our local industries.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, as draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market, I am very pleased with parliament's work on this issue.  Geographical indications for non-agricultural products represent an extraordinary opportunity not only to protect the productive sectors that today achieve wealth and employment, but also to keep alive a cultural and social heritage of which our continent is rich. Protecting geographical indications means above all promoting a vision of Europe. We do not give in to those who think of reducing our Union only to a trading platform. Instead, thanks to innovation and tradition, we want it to remain a place where beauty and quality are produced.  That is why I hope that the Commission will take parliament's strong signal by proposing as soon as possible a system of effective unitary protection, which will protect consumers and producers and which will defend our quality products throughout the world.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, a number of traditional products based on know-how and traditional techniques form part of the European Union's cultural heritage and contribute to strengthening the local economy, supporting the employment and activity of small and medium-sized enterprises. Measures must therefore be taken to protect non-agricultural products from unfair competition in order to preserve traditional skills and the reputation of a geographical indication which is an intangible collective good.  In order to do this, we must do what we do with PDOs, Designation of Origin Products, in the agricultural sector. However, we must not go to the other end, because the measures recently taken by the Commission to impose a sharp excise duty on Traditional Greek drinks, such as tsikoudia and tsipouro, break up viticulture, lead to unemployment among winegrowers and create problems for the local community.  It is therefore necessary to exclude and protect traditional drinks, in particular small producers of tsipouro and tsikoudia.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Mr President, one of the roles that eurosceptics play in this Chamber is that we are here to provide a little balance, because if you hear no dissenting voice on an issue then legislation can end up going through on the nod. In that context, I would like to point out three concerns with regard to geographical indications. First of all, they create barriers for new businesses’ entry into a particular market. If you have a geographical indication – say for example on one type of cheese – it can make it harder for a new business selling cheese to set up in that area. Secondly, they narrow competition and that means that consumers can often have less choice, rather than more choice. Thirdly, they fix capital within a particular geographical area, which may not always be in the strategic interest of the country concerned, or of the region concerned.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: - Mr. President, I want to fully support the Rapporteur and the Committee. I find this an extraordinary subject. As we have done in the agricultural sector, the same should be done in the non-agricultural sector.  I am committed to upholding the authenticity of the product. When it comes to Croatia from agriculture we also had Neretva mandarin and Istrian prosciutto and recently Lico potatoes, but when it comes to intangible heritage then we also have Slavonian gold embroidery and Pag lace and Brač stone, and here today I want to inaugurate embroidery from Konavle, Konavle embroidery from the surroundings of Dubrovnik.  So it's up to us to support this because the fact and projections that speak to four million new jobs are not to be dismissed. So we have to support small businesses, we have to support small and micro entrepreneurs because that's what we base our European economy on.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: – Mr President, I too would like to express my full support and support for the rapporteur's initiative, because the European Union is indeed very rich in quality non-agricultural products, based on traditional knowledge and techniques that are deeply rooted in the cultural and social heritage of our peoples and regions, and that we must help them thrive and develop , thus also contributing to the setting of the means of life in these territories. I believe that the European Union is not taking full advantage of the potential it would have if regulation really existed, the protection of geographical indications of these quality non-agricultural products. Only fifteen Member States have legislation on the protection of geographical indications relating to non-agricultural products. There is no protection of the European Union and we believe that this regulation could really be helped. It would also be harmonious and would agree with the defence of the European single market. Quality products in Spain, in my constituency, such as Castellón ceramics, such as aldaia fans or as is Elda and Elche footwear deserve protection so that thousands and thousands of families living from their work can continue to do so.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: – Commissioner, let me first of all thank our rapporteur, Virginia Rozière, and other colleagues for the excellent work they have done on this report. Extending the protection of geographical indications to non-agricultural products can have a number of positive effects for their producers, consumers and regions as a whole.  Traditional land-specific craft products also represent an important element of Europe's historical and cultural heritage and it is desirable to promote their access to the internal market through common rules and their effective enforcement. The system should be accompanied by the creation of a single European register. In this context, I would stress that product registration must be subject to continuous monitoring to ensure that products consistently comply with the criteria for this label. This will help to increase consumer confidence in branded products.  I therefore join the calls on colleagues for the Commission to present the relevant legislative proposal as soon as possible, and I trust, Commissioner, that you too will support this.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: – Dear Mr President, Honourable Commissioner, I strongly support the introduction of a single system for the protection of geographical indications for non-agricultural products at European Union level. The positives of introducing a single protection at European level are many. First, it will stimulate the technological economic development of certain areas in Europe and increase the number of people employed in the production of traditional goods. Secondly, the promotion of local and regional traditional products is important not only for ensuring fair pay for local producers, but also for creating the conditions for the development of sustainable cultural tourism. In conclusion, I mean that there is a real risk that traditional crafts and methods of production will disappear irrevocably, and we cannot afford this. I therefore call on the Commission to develop and propose, in a short timeframe, an appropriate legislative framework.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: – Mr President, I too wanted to take the floor to congratulate the rapporteur on this initiative and to support it, of course, in her request to the Commission to launch a legislative initiative in this regard.  I believe that it is a crucial issue to improve the competitiveness of many small and medium-sized enterprises, and also to improve consumer safety through the quality certificate that many companies around the European Union have been demanding from us. It is also important – as mentioned here – for the promotion of our culture and the preservation of our heritage. We therefore have great interest in this initiative being launched from countries such as Spain, where we also have long experience, satisfactory and success, in terms of the food sector and we believe that it can also be crucial to develop sectors as important as that of the Origin platform, which is one of the platforms that captures the largest number of associations in Europe behind this request. Therefore, only insist on this need to recognize Macael marble, Ubrique skin, Cordoba jewelry, among many other quality certifications in Europe.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank in particular the rapporteur, Ms Rozière, for her report on the establishment of a geographical indication protection system at EU level for non-agricultural products. The Commission had decided to put this idea to the test through a Green Paper and a public consultation in summer 2014. The results of the consultation, published in June of this year, were supportive of such a system. Let me remind you what the situation is about. A geographical indication identifies goods as originating from a country, region or locality where a particular quality, reputation or other characteristic of the product is linked to its geographical origin: for example, Bordeaux wine, Murano glass or Irish whiskey. Agriculture products such as cheeses, wines, meats, fruits and vegetables from a specific geographical origin, possessing certain qualities or made according to traditional methods, may be afforded EU-wide geographical indication protection. However, non-agricultural products, such as ceramics, marble, cutlery, shoes, tapestries and musical instruments, do not, to date, enjoy unitary geographical indication protection at EU level beyond national laws. That is, for instance, the case of Carrara marble from Italy, Solingen knives from Germany, Koniaków lace from Poland or Haapsalu mud from Estonia.  Moving towards a system of non-agricultural geographical indications would be a major step, the costs and benefits of which would need to be assessed very carefully. What we do know is that direct and indirect employment in the sectors producing geographically-rooted non-agricultural products has been estimated at around four million jobs. On the positive side, I can see four benefits. First, safeguarding jobs and wealth in economically fragile areas: two-thirds of the regions from which non-agricultural geographical indication products originate have a poverty rate or an unemployment rate above 20%. Second, encouraging tourism: geographical indication products have always been innovating using traditional knowhow or cultural heritage. The underlying image of quality can have a significant impact on the attractiveness of regions at local and international level. Third, increasing the distinctiveness and attraction of the relevant products would help increase sales volumes and thus the competitiveness of European businesses – mostly small and medium enterprises – as was the case for agricultural products. Fourth, helping consumers make more informed choices while preventing fraudulent use of geographical indications. Beyond these issues and as your report also points out, there would be positive effects on trade relations with third countries too. Indeed, an EU-wide protection system could positively impact our bilateral negotiations with emerging and developing countries interested in securing better protection for their geographical indication products in the EU. At multilateral level in the World Trade Organisation, the EU’s negotiating efforts to improve the level of protection for geographical indications would also benefit from an extension of the protection to non-agricultural products.  However, there are also drawbacks. Such a system would imply quite far-reaching regulatory intervention, the proportionality of which will need to be assessed very carefully.  Your report brings an important input to the ongoing reflection on an EU-wide protection system for non-agricultural geographical indications. The Commission will consider your recommendations with attention and will continue to reflect, with all interested parties, on a possible way forward.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The debate has been closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 6 October 2015. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. – Expanding the EU system of geographical indicators to include non-agricultural goods would mean greater protection, transparency and information for both EU consumers and producers. European consumers will be better informed about the quality and origin of the product they are buying. The skills of producers will be recognised and protected in a more coherent manner. By also securing the prestige of local European handicraft, this could, importantly, help in bringing growth and securing jobs in the local areas that produce these products. In order to feel the full economic benefits of this EU-wide protection, we must ensure that information on the system reaches all consumers and producers. A unitary EU level of protection, however, should not mean the elimination of protection at national level. Not all producers will need protection at EU level, particularly those who run their business in only one state. The EU unitary system should thus coexist with the Member State level so that producers may choose the type of protection that will best meet their needs.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. – Hungary and the food industry are of particular importance in the european economy. The same can be said of wine production closely linked to these industries, but the country boasts a number of traditionally high-quality products in addition to agricultural land. Designations such as Szeged peppers, Gyula sausages, macaque onions, Tokaj wine or Eger bull's blood, which are recognised on the international stage, not only contribute to the colouring of the image of the country of origin, but also, in addition to maintaining the quality requirements of the products, represent a significant added market value through protection in the form of collective entitlement.  In general, the concept of geographical indications is used as a collective name for all the signs used in circulation to identify the geographical origin of products. At present, at European level, the protection of origin provided by geographical indications covers only agricultural products meeting the conditions. This own-initiative report calls on the European Commission to also come forward with a legislative proposal for products that do not fall within the scope of agricultural products and which, by their traditional production, form part of the European cultural heritage. I think this is a good idea, and I propose a thorough study of the well-established Hungarian Hungarikum concept on this subject.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. – I believe that traditions reinforce our roots and promote development. Portugal is very rich in handicrafts, embroidery and ceramics. These products should benefit from a European system for the protection of geographical indications. In this way, we protect the production method, tie the product to the site, preserve knowledge and jobs and give reliable information to the consumer. This legislation should promote innovation in traditional production processes and the creation of new companies, as has happened in Portugal and, above all, in Minho, as evidenced by the scarves of lovers of Vila Verde and the initiative Namorar Portugal. It should be noted that micro-enterprises and small businesses account for around 80% of typical local products. Viana embroidery, Guimarães embroidery and The Vinhais Mask are examples of products that can benefit from the legislation I defend.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. An extension of geographical indications to non-agricultural products would be a real economic and cultural opportunity in Europe. As rapporteur for the EPP on the opinion of the Committee on International Trade on this subject, I would like to point out that direct and indirect employment in the non-agricultural geographical indications sector accounts for more than 4 million jobs in Europe and that in 2010 the estimated value of sales for the Geographical Indications of the European Union was EUR 54.3 billion, of which EUR 11.5 billion was export sales. Many European and French products could be affected by this European device, including the Laguiole knife, the Calais lace or the Cherbourg umbrella.  Protecting the geographical indications of non-agricultural products at European level would not only protect our companies from counterfeiting and unfair competition, but also ensure that consumers know how and quality products. The future system will have to be accessible to our businesses, especially our SMEs, and therefore simple and inexpensive. The signal to the Commission is clear and we expect a legislative initiative from it.

name: Damiano ZOFFOLI
text: in writing. I consider it very important to establish a geographical indication mark for non-agricultural products as well. There are many artisanal productions, typical of specific territories, which are disappearing due to the entry into the market of low-cost productions. The establishment of geographical indication would ensure an extra weapon in the fight against imports from countries such as China or India, as well as certifying for consumers the origin of the product from quality production areas. I believe it is essential that the use of the name should be free of charge and accessible to all producers in a given area who produce products according to the methods envisaged. Furthermore, I strongly believe that extending geographical indications can help to make the EU's position more coherent at international level, so as to protect all European quality products in bilateral and multilateral trade negotiations. Finally, the IG label would increase the transparency of raw materials and the traceability of products with a view to having adequate tools at their disposal for the suppression of fraud.
